Picked up single 12-oz bottle from Heritage Liquors in Maplewood, MN. Pours a clear golden straw colored brew with an average sized off-white head that quickly dissipates. Aroma of grapefruit zest, white pepper, a touch of celery and some golden grain malt. Taste is light bodied with flavors of a typical regular grapefruity and mild citrus with some toasted biscuit malt. Finish is semi-dry at first with a lingering bitterness that slowly disappears. Tongue shock recovery time, about 2 minutes. A solid session IPA.

Pours gold with a frothy white head that dissipates to a thin layer. Substantial cling. Aromas of sweet citrus and floral hops. Flavors of sweet stone fruit, cut grass, bread, slight herbal tones and floral hops. Clean mouthfeel. Delicious.
33 cl. bottle. Clear golden colour with a white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, fruit, hops, citrus, grass and bitterness.

Bottle
Consummation: hoppy, grapefruit, ctrus
Adjunct: Fucking spiders everywhere...not random; sweet peach

Pours very light hazy gold. Head as white as Santa’s beard. Minimal bubbles resigning from the bottom of the glass. Aroma of oranges, honey and brown sugar. Interesting aroma for an IPA. Crisp light flavor. A bit of hoppy bitterness on the finish. None of the sweetness I was expecting based on the aroma. Beer is slightly fuzzy in the mouth. Pretty taste session IPA.

Piney, somewhat Creamy nose (due to brioche-y malt), but with a bit of grassy and [steak] pepper sauce. Pretty rounded fruits on the tongue (apple, lemon, pear?). Nice, but let’s be honest - if the big selling point is flavour at low ABV, there are definitely better ones out there. UK’s Siren QIPA is v good. Similar strength, but slightly better, from US is Stone’s Go-To IPA.

Bottle. A light golden pour with a nice white head. Aroma is hoppy, light fruits, smells sweet. Flavor is mild. It’s crisp and refreshing. A lighter session IPA. The lower alcohol does make it a good choice for summer.

12 ounce bottle. Clear white gold with a big fluffy white head. Interesting lacing. A nice big classic west coast IPA aroma with a lot of pine. The flavor has lesser pine with grass and lemon. Tropical fruit with mangoes and pears. I like a flavorful session IPA.

Pours a greenish yellow color. Slight haze. White head, about two fingers. Good retention, good lacing.

Aroma is pine bark, orange zest, mango. It’s light, but very nice.

Taste is pine resin, orange zest, mango. Bready, and grassy hops. It is pretty bright in the taste.

Mouthfeel is medium light. It’s clean, bright, refreshing. I think it does the trick. Great for sessioning.

Overall, it’s good. I like the brightness of it. Good IPA qualities, but toned down. I would buy this again, I would probably recommend this. It’s not great as an IPA, but as a session IPA, I think it’s one of the best.

Rating #1715 - 2015.06.02 - Bottle brought back from Palm Liquor. Killer tropical punch erupting from this foaming straw-coloured pour. Lemon rind, grapefruit, cookie dough. Palate is more citrus, decent bitterness for a session, and a fair malt backbone. Crushable beach beer.

Gylden, let perlende og let diset, Session IPA med æggehvidlig hvid skumkrone på ungefär 2 cm, hvor sidstnævnte svinder til et par mm. 
Skøn frugtrig, humlet og blomsteragtig aroma af appelsin, citron og grapefrugt. 
Dejlig let smag og skøn ligetil! Frisk, på trods af at have passeret udløbsdatoen, sprød og let drikkelig. Middel bitterhed og lille sødme. 
Middel fyldig krop med en fin, frisk og tilpas karbonering. Konsistensen er olieret, og afslutningen moderat bitter. 
Overall: Perfekt øl og smag på netop denne varme (25*) sommerdag. Kunne sagtens have en ramme af denne liggende fast i køleren. 
(355 ml)/12 oz's, 4.6 % ABV, BB: 06/16, købt i Meny i Rotunden i Hellerup.

Bottle. A more or less clear one, golden in color and topped by a small, white head. The aroma is rather hoppy, piney, citrusy hop pellets, with little room left for the malts. It has a nice, suitable bitterness, it’s quite dry, and with a nice carbonation level. Some citrus peel, a good dash of pine cones, some pale malts and a touch of bread in the flavor. Lasting hop dominated finish with a nice drying bitterness. Some oily, citrusy notes too, like chewing on orange peel. Didn’t like that very much, but it’s just a touch of it so no points deducted. Anyway, it’s a quite refreshing beer that I could drink a bunch of. 150622

Bottle 355ml @ Hotel room, The Latham Hotel, Philadelphia, PA

Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, citrus, grape, pine and orange. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter with a long citrus, grape and piney finish. Body is light to medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.

DayTime is suitable name for this session-able brew. It pours the color of sunshine with a fluffy layer of cloud cover on top. Aroma is like the stuff that grows in the sunshine: grass, flowers, and trees (okay, pine). Flavor captures the best of each. Grassy freshness, floral nectar, and bittersweet pine sap. There are also some toasted biscuit flavors from the malt and hint of green tea earthiness. The mouthfeel is crisp and supremely refreshing. Not too sticky, not too bitter - it hits the happy medium in about every way. If you need some hops in your life before sundown, DayTime is the way to do it.

Bottled. Pours an exceptionally pale gold. Light cat pee aroma, with soft tropical fruit notes. It has a thin body, yet is very satisfying, with a rounded mouthfeel, that gives a jammy finish. 

The comparison below to Coors Light below is very bizarre.....

Aroma: light tropical fruits, some minerals, light pine. Appearance: clear gold, small, frothy head. Taste: light sweet. Palate: soft carbonation, light body, tropical fruits, light bitters coming up, some citrus. Overall: excellent Session IPA, light and yet quite complex. Bottle at The Carpenters Arms, Marylebone.

This is the worst attempt I have found for a session IPA. In my opinion Lagunitas is one of the finest craft brewers and I find it hard to believe they would release a product that looks, smells, and tastes like Coors Lite or hopped up bong water.
Bottle 0.355l at Uusi Apteekki, Turku. Originally rated 20150606. Colour is orange with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Fruits, citrus, hops and malts.

Very pale golden, no rousable head. Nose is creamy sweet, grassy and wet breadcrumbs. Initial taste isn’t robust, just feels it’s way in nicely. Short stack bitterness, clean and lean mouthfeel and unstressed carbonation. Finishes a bit more of this fruity sweetness, prickly pine and focused on smashability. Clean smash good times. Bottle, Cornelius.

Bottle to shaker glass. Pours clear light golden, two finger frothy white head. Nice lacing and retention. Aroma of lemon zest. Taste is moderately bitter, toasty light malt sweetness. Light bodied, lively carbonation, smooth but a little watery in the mouth. Finishes dry. Tasting notes of toasted malt, bread, lemon, apricot and light pine. A very fine session IPA!
Draught@Tommyknocker's. Pale golden color, lasting white head. Citric hop aroma. Aromatic hop flavor, fruity notes. Medium-light body, medium carbonation. Nice, summer beer!

Bottle from BottleDog. It pours clear pale gold with a decent white head. The nose is soft, juicy, toasty, soft peach and apricot. The taste is crisp, refreshingly bitter, toasty grass, peach, apricot, straw, pepper and minerals with a bone dry finish. Light body and moderate, prickly carbonation. Crisp and crazy crushable. Just how a session IPA outta be.

On draft. Pours light yellow, thin fizzy head. Aroma is light floral hops, some pine. Taste is quite dry, clean, floral, a little grassy. Pleasant enough, but thin and less hoppy than the best sessions.

[Bottle (12oz)] Pours a cloudy yellow-gold with an average size diminishing frothy white head. Nice aroma of tropical fruit and fruity hops first followed by bready malt. Flavour follows, a bit lighter and waterier then the aroma suggests but it’s still good and enjoyable. Moderate bitter finish. Average bodied. Pretty nice and enjoyable.

Aroma floral, resin, citrus, spruce, 
Appearance pale, golden, clear, frothy, white foam, 
Taste light sweetness, medium bitterness, 
Palate medium body, lively, 
Overall a good session ipa but not the best. Still I would suggest this beer to a friend

12 oz. bottle purchased at Craft Beer Cellar, Portsmouth, NH. Dark brown or dark ruby in color, thin lasting head. Aroma of light floral hops, sweet grain and notes of scallions, grassy. 

 
The body is light and crisp with a drying affect on the tongue. Flavor is pretty much spot on the aromas. Grassy, traces of scallion with a light grain backbone. Bitterness is on the low side with a pleasing tingle of carbonation over the palate. I liked this much more than I was expecting. Very nice session brew.

355ml bottle from Brewdog online store. Clear golden colour, frothy white foam head and aroma of tropical fruity passionfruit, floral, hoppy. Taste is malt caramel with passionfruit, citrusy orange, hop resin bitterness. Creamy mouthfeel, light bodied, soft carbonation, dry floral hoppy bitter finish. Very drinkable.
12 Oz bottle poured into tulip glass. Great hop presence, low malt. Good session IPA.
Hop water. Big resiny bong water nose. Thin golden body with little head retention. Some light malt to balance. Not bitter. This is all about the aroma hops. Not to my liking.
Bottle. Very faint aroma of lemon peel. Clear golden body. Flavor has a crisp heavy hop feel with a high carbonated mouth feel.
I had it from the bottle. This was a nice and refreshing IPA. You get your hops and some nice grapefruit and other citrus. The citrus was more pronounced here.

355ml bottle at home from Good Spirits Co, Glasgow (£2.60):

I was quite disappointed with this one from Lagunitas, it definitely seems like the worst of 3 beers that I’ve tried thus far from them & came out almost like a watered down version of their regular IPA that I much preferred to this one, as well as being one that I can picked up more easily & for cheaper too. It’s not that I didn’t enjoy this one or that I thought it was a bad beer, it’s just that I felt it could have been so much better & I was expecting it be.
Would drink again, no evil hop after taste, refreshingly snappy. My second beer from this brewery.
Great easy drinking session ipa with a great hop profile for a session beer

Bottle from Bottledog and drunk on a train. Kinda kicking into the session ipa style. A good one though. Still it’s not a lager so who cares? Over carbonated. It’s really drinkable. Love the peach apricot grapefruit orange flavours like orange squash on the finish. Just a little toasty on the hops. And carbonic acid. Otherwise pretty damn good.

Deep yellow pour with slight clinging foamy head. Aroma is light bready malt and a lot of citrus. Flavor is light slightly sweet malt with a solid citrus flavor. Medium lasting bitter for me. Light/medium body with slightly aggressive carbonation. Another solid ipa under 5%.

Bottle from The Beerhive. Clear golden body with a thin white head. Low carbonation. Light lacing. Aroma of cucumber, salted lemon and tangerine. Flavour of pink grapefruit, lychee and watermelon sweets. Thin body with an oily mouthfeel. Soft fizz. Sweet and fruity.

12oz bottle from The Beer Store Wilson. Golden hue, normal clarity with somewhat lasting white fizzy head. Virtually no lacing (I think there is something wrong with my snifter) Aroma of orange citrus hop, grapefruit and lemon, some floral notes as well. Light citrus grapefruit hop up front with more of a lemon zest finish. Fizzy on palate, good mouthfeel. Okay, but not my favorite Lagunitas brew.

Tasted on draft at 2015 St. Louis Microfest in a willi becher glass. It poured a crystal clear golden colour with sudsy white foam and lace. Bigger aroma than flavour. True-to-style American Pale Ale: grainy, grapefruity, dank. Light body, strong carbonation, hoppy aftertaste. Good not great.
Bottle from Chevy Chase Beer and Wine. Nice amber body with medium head. Nose is hoppy and sweet. Taste is hoppy also and prickly. Texture is prickly. Herbal and smooth in the finish.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a medium, well retained, white head, with heavy lacing, over a slightly hazy yellow (SRM 3) body......nose is pine, resin, citrus peel from the hops, light cereal malts, balance to the hops......taste is heavily to the hops, with pine, resin, grapefruit, light floral tones, light cereal, balance heavily to the hops....mouth feel, light body, no alcohol, high carbonation. This is a light refreshing, quenching, hop delivery vehicle. It fall into the category, and really does taste good unlike some others in the style. They are all, however, in many ways, highly hopped Pale Lagers.BJCP 8/3/14/4/8

Bottle from Plaid Pantry. Light golden straw in color. Nose is sort of sweet with tropical fruit notes, followed by some more pungent bitterness. Good and bitter throughout. The body is a little lacking. Pretty tasty sessional brew.

Bottle 330ml.
Pours very clear blond with low white head. Aroma is of citrus, fruits. Taste is of citrus, bitterness, flowers, fruits. Palate: Light body. Soft-medium carbonation. Overall: Quite good. Nice hop action.
This is when it was eden.. This beer is what you crave when its day drinking time.
Pretty good but Lagunitas IPA is better................................................
Pours a clear gold with a hint of orange and a fluffy white head. Aroma of cat and tropical fruit and grain. Flavour is grainy and slightly bitter. Body is thin to medium. Finish is dry and bitter.

Golden colored body, medium to thin white head, spotty lacing. Mild citrus, lychee, florals, and white grape. Medium to light bodied with moderate carbonation, pleasant bitterness, clean, refreshing finish.

Bottle from Epsom Circle Market, Epsom NH. Aroma is hoppy with grapefruit and pine. Appearance is hazy, pale greenish yellow--looks like a cross between a Hefeweizen and, I don’t mean to be gross, urine. Head is negligible white with moderate retention and no lacing to speak of. Taste is balanced moderately bitter and sweet. It’s right at the threshold of my hop tolerance so it OK by me but probably more loved by acolytes of the style. Palate is light bodied, slightly oily texture with lively carbonation that lights up the front and side of the tongue. Finish is long, dry and mildly bitter at back roof of the mouth and upper jaw.
355ml bottle. Golden color, thin white head. Gooseberries, fresh, fruity aroma. Flavor has gooseberries, citrus, kiwi. Nice bitterness. Thin body. Nice session beer.

Clear golden pour w/ a retaining foamy white head that leaves lacing. The aroma is of sweet & citrus hops. The flavor is quite clean until a nice hop bitterness towards the end. It’s medium bodied but light & certainly sessionable as there is no dryness in the aftertaste. Pretty good!
Great beer. It’s Delicious and not very filling. Drink up it’s really good!
highly session-able beer. floral with hints of citrus. light on the sugar, with just a bit of sour character. looks great, tastes great!

Draft at Barrel Republic. Pours clear gold with a fizzy white head. Tastes like grapefruit, lemon, toasted malt, smooth, creamy mellow citrus, lemon, grapefruit, fruity, toasty malt. Light body and low carbonation. Smells grapefruit, lemon, toasted malt, citrus hops.

35,5 cl bottle @ home

No freshness or ABV info

Aroma has tropical fruits and pineapple juice. Flavour has grapefruit, resiny tones, gooseberry bush and some caramel. Finishes a bit vichy-like. A session IPA on the sweet side.
Very bright and crisp. Fruity with a strong lychee flavor and background citrus notes. Perfect summer day beer.

Bottle (12 oz) bought @ Cambridge Wine & Spirits. Hotel Room Tasting.



Appearance: Clear pale golden with a small white head and little lacing. 



Aroma: Grains, crackery malts, herbal/leafy notes and mild citrus. 



Taste: Mild. Crackery malts, herbal/leafy presence, mild citrus and very low bitterness. 



Palate: Light body. Medium carbonation. Dry and herbal finish. 



Overall: The comparison with FW Easy Jack probably didn’t help as this one is much less aromatic but it’s still a good clean, crisp and quenching beer.
Decent session beer. Good hoppy aroma. A little thin on the body and palate with a harsh finish.

Pours a clear light golden wih a small white head that leaves low lacing. Nose is of fruits - litchees - and juicy. Taste is of pears and just fruity overall. Body is medium, carbonation light to moderate. Overall a nice one, really pleasing.

Bottle at hotel tasting. Very pale gold pour with white head. Aroma is leafy, nice grassy, leafy hop, light lemon. Taste is light, very light leafy hop taste, small bitterness. Palate is light bodied, light carbonation. Nice.
Aroma of citrus, grass, lime, some floral notes, fresh hops. Flavour is light sweet with a medium bitter finish. Quite refreshing and hoppy, it does the job nicely.

12 oz. bottle served in a shaker- poured a transparent thin yellow color, an enchanting foamy two finger plus head formed from the time it took to pour, relieve myself, muse about taking a photo, grabbed a soda, sat down, lit a smoke and had a few drags, and wrote this (7-10 minutes). Aroma of pine and resin. Hits the mouth with a light-medium body, malt is very restrained and light, middle has some light sweetness, finish is only lightly acidic. Old bottle perhaps?

Very light in color, the hops will do the talking here. Late hanging Simcoe onion/grass smell along with citrus and grapefruit. This beer is plucky, it's light, delivers great. Refreshing floral hop characteristics with a small amount of hop bitterness to keep you coming back. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Standard session. Clear gold, fluffy white head. Crisp and clean. Solid option for a long day.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Pours clear golden with a small white head. Mainly hops in the aroma, including floral, citrus and tropical fruit notes. Moderate sweetness and bitterness, bitter finish.
Bottle. Earthy orange malt and pine/lemon peel aroma. Pale yellow with moderate white head. Lightly sweet earthy lemon malt and mildly bitter lemon peel flavor. Light body. Not bad.

Bottle poured a super light golden in color with a thin coating of white head. Aroma has bright hops, onion, and some citrus. Mouth feel is light with good carbonation. Flavor has alright hops, citrus, and pines. Looking carefully now I see the cryptic date code in dark print on the neck of the bottle and this is six months old. Explains it all :(

On bottle at Gustavs in Sälen. Clean golden color, good foam. Immediately intense hoppy, grapefruit- some fruitiness. Medium body & complexity. Solid bitterness, maybe unbalanced in that regard. Enjoyable 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

There are much better session iPA’s on the market, ones you can read a clear best by date on the bottle so you drink them fresh. Lagunitas hides in code only someone who researched it could figure out then prints in dark black so you can’t see it. Very clear straw color, decent citrus hops on the nose but are not as pronounced in the taste. Moderately dry, easy drinking, not bad but there are so many better session IPA’s if your going to spend the money.

Pours golden with a rich white head. Crisp smell of hops and citrus. Taste is subtle with hops, some syrup and lemon grass. palate is a bit too thin and oily. Overall a nice beer though I wish for a richer taste.
First experience with a session IPA. Crisp, clean, and refreshing. This beer met my hops craving.
Bottle. Very pale, clear gold. Aroma has citrus and pine hops as well as some apple. Flavour has some sweet fruit and finishes bitter.

Clear, light-yellow beer with a one finger high head that dissapears fast. A little lacing stays on the glass. 

Nose: Green apple, pear, grapefruit, grass, pineapple, citrus and crackers.
Taste: Citrus, wheat and pine.
Body: Light body wwith a crisp carbonation. Oily texture. 

Easy drinkable Session IPA!

Bottled@Guitars, Umeå. Yellowish golden colour, mediumsized white head. Aroma is fruity, floral, mild resin, sap and some pleasant citrus to it. Flavour is fruity, floral, nectary and has some wooden and earthy notes as well. A bit catpissy as it warms up. Tasty and refreshing session beer.

Bottle: Golden, nearly banana-shade of yellow with decent clarity. Foamy white head settles to a thin layer leaving some lacing behind. Aroma is kind of muted. Mild bouquet of citrus rind, grapefruit, pineapple, & other vague, albeit zesty fruit notes. More akin to the bitter "peel" side of things, rather than juicy & fleshy. Herbal, floral, & mild piney back-end hop notes. Crispy & wet with each sip, seems just a touch watered down. Even for a "session" IPA. Floral hops, hints of white pepper, grassy bitterness, a touch of hop oil. Mid-palate showcases more of the fruity side of the hops; citrus peel, grapefruit pith, tangerine rind. A very, very small bit of cracker malt towards the finish. Fairly solid session IPA choice, but perhaps slightly vapid, even considering the style. I’d choose Founders’ All Day IPA over this every single time.

pours unclear pale yellow with a frothy white head very danky and bright grassiness, spicy melons, green citrus - limes, tropicalness - fruits and coconut, pale lean spicy and crackery maltiness, tequila, tea - astringency, pepper. light carbonation, light body - fluffy and not really watery; balanced grassy-spicy-citrusy finish. solid session ipa.
Pale golden yellow pour with a white head. Aroma is piney hops. Taste is piney hops, a nice malt base. Pine finish and lasting aftertaste. OK lacing. Tasty session beer.

This beer pours a slight hazy yellow golden color with a thick soapy white head that left some good lacing around the glass. The aroma pine, hops, citrus, lemon peel, and mild breadiness. The taste is very subdued compared to the aroma, as if it were their normal ipa watered down. As a session ipa and for the style I am sure that is what they are going for with this beer. I pick up the hop resin, pine, citrus, and breadiness. The mouthfeel is light and somewhat dry and the drinkability is high.

This pours a deep golden into the glass, with a nice stocky head that reduces to a medium cap that leaves webbed lacing. The nose is of citrus rinds and pine needles. Nice hopping throughout, well-bittered, with grapefruit, pine resin and lemon zest, finishing with tropical citrus rind/peel and fresh spruce-pine. The mouthfeel is medium-light and the palate is active; that is, without overactive carbonation... well-integrated and not over-the-top. Zesty, fresh, citric and bitter (via low ABV), this makes for a great session IPA. Really nice take on the newer style. Does what it says it will do... provide a nice IPA session brew. Prost!
Light yellow colored. Light pine aroma. Light malt and grapefruit taste. Light bodied. Well-lit!

Bottle at Guitars, Umeå. Slightly hazy yellow color, good cloudy white head. Lime, orange and grapefruit in the nose. Light-bodied. Gooseberry, pale maltyness. Light citrus notes. Sessionable but quite simple.

Flaska från Craftbeer/Galatea. Lagunitas bidrag till Sessiontrenden. Gyllengul, lätt disig, högt vitt skum. Mycket fin fruktig humledoft med aprikoser, mandariner, ananas, mango mm. Stora smaker men lätt kropp i bra balans. Lätt karamellig och kexig rund mjuk kropp, fin fruktig humle, rena smaker, måttlig/lätt beska, kort eftersmak. En riktigt trevlig session-IPA.
Flaska från craftbeer/galatea. Smak och doft av humle, jäst, citrus med toner av karamell och örter. Rund och len. Lätt kropp och sötma. Beska mes smak av citrusskal.

Light yellow with big white head; Piney grapefruit hop aroma. Very light body with big emphasis on pine/grapefruit hop aroma and flavors. This is a great "daytime" ale, yes its light in body, light in malt feel, even though its a hoppy beer its not particularly bitter or heavy in hop flavor. I would drink this again.

Aroma: Pine and resin hop aromas with hints of toasted malts in the background.
Appearance: Clear gold with a rich white head.
Taste: Medium bitterness with a light sweetness. Very well balanced.
Palate: Light body, slick texture, soft carbonation, long clean finish. 
Overall: A nice, quaffable brew. Meant to be light, and it is, but still has the flavors of a heartier beer. Good attempt.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a pint glass.
Aroma-Has a nice hoppy citrus aroma.
Appearance- Pours like a BMC but with a large white head, looks are deceiving.
Taste- Has a great IPA flavor with a nice hoppy aftertaste bite.
Palate- A crisp light bodied brew with medium carbonation.
Overall- A really strong beer from Lagunitas (duhh, arent’ they all??) this is a must to try.

12 oz bottle. At the Pork and More, Tampere, Finland. 

Slightly cloudy yellow colour with a small white head. 
Fruity hops, mild tartness, some sweetness and malt in the aroma. Nice! 
The flavour is sweet fruity hops, mild bitterness and mild maltiness. Very drinkable. Balanced. Rich and full for a 4.65% brew.

12 oz bottle. Pours a super clear gold, light white head lasting lace. Aroma is light wheat, grain, fresh citrus. Flavor is wheat, grass, hay, light lasting bitter. Nice sesh IPA. Thin body, well carbonated.

Bottled at Bishop’s Arms Linnégatan, Stockholm.  Hazy pale golden, brief head. Peachy hop aroma. Mid sweet with light body and clean mouthfeel. Perfumy flavur with peach and mango, also paper. Mid bitter finish.
Это пиво вкусное. я, конечно, рекомендую его всем, что любит хорошую Craft пива!

Wow. Looks like a fizzy light macro. Glad it isn't. As pale as it gets with a surprising amount of malt to balance the hops. I'm not an ipa drinker, this is an easy top 5 ipa for me. I really enjoyed drinking this beer, I wish more ipas were like this one. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

My Bottom Line:

Chewy cereals are surrounded by citrus fruit, flowers and ginger connotations in this fashionable, refreshing Pale Ale.



Further Personal Perceptions:

-A veil of foam sits atop the misty golden.

-Mouthfeel is quite prickly and more chewy than expected.

-The bitterness is moderate, with a few sandy resins.

-The hop fruitiness is also reminiscent of gooseberries.



Bottle.

Great aroma of fruity hops. Taste was hops but not as much as you'd expect from the aroma. Not very bitter and actually a bit on the lighter tasting side. Lots of carbonation. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured into a tumbler on 05.31.14.

A: 2 finger fluffy white head. Crystal clear straw yellow body.

S: Strong grapefruit and malt sweetness.

T: Grapefruit and sweet malt dominate. Flower and pine are subtle.

M: Creamy. Perfect carbonation.

O: This is a fantastic session IPA. It somehow manages to have complexity and it has a perfect balance. The grapefruit flavor isn’t as strong as in other Lagunitas beers, but again, it is a session beer.
Bottle in Seattle. Very pale yellow, soapy foam. Perfumey fruity hop. Apricots. Sweet and fruity beer, mild body, sparkling carbonation. nice beer

bottle - Pours gold with a one finger head and a rich citrus hop aroma. The flavor is of crisp, aggressively bitter hops, citrus, and toasted malt. It’s easy drinking and quite tasty, maybe the best of the session IPAs I’ve tried so far.

12oz bottle pours clear gold yellow with a finger of head. Nose is bright citrus, pear, orange, pineapple, grassy with a touch of round cracker malt. Taste is similar to nose with some nice grassy pine and soft resin, light (but not thin) body, medium bitterness, and clean light malt. Finish is balanced bitteness, lemon, grassy orange, pear, citrus. Excellent.
Bottle from Total Wine. Light pour with a white head. Aroma is sappy and citrus with bread. Taste is a little bitter, bready, and citrus. Nice finish.

Bottle purchased at Elevated. Consumed with commonshawn in a Belgian snifter glass. Very light golden color with a noticeable amount of head. Lemony, citrus aroma. Quite vibrant. Grassy notes come to the forefront at the initial taste. Bitter characteristics pick up as the sip moves forward finishing light and bitter. The flavor is bright but the bitterness kind of overwhelms. Sessionable with the hoppy Lagunitas stamp. Probably made for a hot summer day not a winter afternoon in Mpls. Not one of my favorites.

Bottle with commonmac. Light gold with frothy white head that doesn’t last long. Pine hop and a bit of citrus nose. Bitter spice, sharp, and crisp. Heavy citrus peel hop bitterness throughout. Tastes like an ipa version of this style, which is not surprising. Good beer, but I like the night version better.
Pours a slightly cloudy golden straw color with white head. Fruity hops on the nose. Slightly sour.
12oz bottle. Golden yellow pour with soapy white head. Aroma is lemony and fresh. Delicious citrus and bright hops come together to accomplish the mission of a daytime drinker. Nice.
bottle from saveur-biere.com. Light gold color. Thin head. Thin body. Taste is medium bitter. Aroma is hoppy, piny, pinneapple.
Bottle. Decent ipa with super light flavor and notes. Pretty solid overall.
Bottle cheers to Jackson. Very citric and zesty stuff. Fairly sweet but it always works with this style. Not out of the ordinary but well made. Good drop

355ml bottle (Black Door, Helsini)

Initially a very tropical citrussy aroma, later some swimming pool minerals. Extremely citrussy in the taste, with the carbonation it’s almost lemonadey. Fairly watery palate, but full enough flavoured to be quite refreshing. Finish citrussy and littlde buttery. A simple golden ale, better than the blander examples from England, but still lacking something.

Bottle. Pale yellow. Mango, tropicals, peachy fruity hoppy with pale maltyness, citrus. Lightish bodied, pale ale bittered, hoppy flavour. Ends in a nice piney finish. Real nice flavourful hoppy pale ale.

-- bb

On the Eighth Day of Christmas the beer gods gave to me . . . a real "light" beer. Pours a golden color with a white foam head. Aroma of caramel, grapefruit, and earthiness. Light sweet caramel taste with a mild but noticeable hop hit and grapefruit notes on the backend. Solid session IPA. Could have used a bit more hops.

(Bottle, 0.355 l - no BBE info found, at Black Door, 20141220) The beer poured golden and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had grapefruit, citricness and mildly pine. Palate was rather light bodied with rather carbonation. Flavours were fruitiness, citricness, pine, sweetness and bitterness. Afteraste was hoppy and bitter. A decent low ABV pale ale but too fizzy.

12 ounce bottle. Pale yellow gold with a big fluffy white head. Fresh citrus hop nose. Crisp biscuit malt flavor is balanced by a subtle dose of citrus and pine hops. Medium bodied and very drinkable. Mildly dry hop finish.
Bottle into a jar in a Chinese restaurant with a medieval themed kung fu movie on. One guess where I am. Citrus with light butter. Beery!

a bright clear light gold color similar to a helles. the aroma is hop dankness, nice grassy tones with a spicy dill component, slight citrus tones, big cascade aromas. the beer is easy going, hop forward with a thirst quenching bitter dryness. low malt flavor allows the hops to shine, nice to have a big bold hop presence without to much bite or alcohol. Nice beer to drink any day of the week.

This is by far one of the better session-style IPAs to hit the market lately that I’ve tasted. I sampled this treat in a bottle at the Chicago taproom. You could definitely tell that the body was a lot lighter than your typical IPA, but that is of course by design. There is still quite a bit of hops with a ton of delicious citrus flavors. There is also a hint of a piney, woody note in the taste. The finish was quite dry and spicy, loaded with hops. A well-done session beer!
Straw color , nice white head. Rich and full IPA's aroma: citrus , spices , caramel . Great refreshing taste , even though less intensive then regular IPA's taste.
Sample at Örebro Öl & Whisky 2014. Hoppy smell with citrus and a grassy dill aroma. Light and hoppy taste. Refreshing.
12oz bottle at home. Perhaps my expectations were too high, but I really was not a fan of this one...OK in aroma, weak in taste, and frankly tastes like a watered-down little sumpin. Disappointed.

BOD 230/14. Crystal clear light amber, golden, pour. World Class massive head, lacing and retention. Outstanding complex nose of citrus (grapefruit, tangerine and light tropicals) over a light biscuit sweetness coupled with a spicy note. Light body with a slightly heavier than water texture when very cold, but thickens up to slightly slick at room temperature. Slightly above normal carbonation with just a bit of effervescence in the middle and a nice burst in the finish. The nice flavor profile is reasonably intense, complex and balanced. For a session ale, it’s rather flavorful. It begins with a blended citrus hop flavor that fades into mild bitterness. As the bitterness fades in the middle, it takes on a rind note over a nice biscuit background sweetness. The finish is crisp and leaves you with a nice lingering tangerine bitterness. Lagunitas has another winner!

Bottle. Pours clear. Straw color. Had lots of bubbles in the bottle, but that didn’t translate to the shaker and has no head. Full IPA hops aroma including the typical floral and pine scents. Caramel and lightly toasted malt aromas in there as well. Flavor is a lighter hops experience, but not watered down at all. Nice malt balance and a lager-esque yeast flavor. Palate is light and refreshing. Overall right on target for what is advertised.

12 oz bottle, served in a shaker pint. Pours bright yellow golden with medium fluffy white head. Aroma is faintly sweet pale straw malt, with sharp grassy vegetal hops on the back. Taste is smooth thin pale malt with lightly bitter hops on the finish. Some crisp earthy, grassy notes on the hops, but not much. Quite honestly not my favorite style, but good flavor for what this is here.

Taste is magnificently balanced and full on such a light and refreshing body...rediculous subtlety and firmness on a light palate. I almost never give a "5" on the palate score for something this light but...wow.

bottle @ Party Town / Florence KY --- Clear light golden amber, fluffy 2" white head, bands of lace. Aroma of sharp pine hops. Taste is solid malt with a little biscuit that rolls into the palate adding medium pine hops on the swallow before yielding once again to sweet malt. An exceptional brew, considering the 4.65% abv, well worth having over and over.

Bottle into a glass. Pours a straw yellow color with a white head. Sadly, my bottle was skunked, so the aroma say not good. Taste was off, but still not terrible.

Lagunitas DayTime has a thin, white head, a yellow-gold appearance, with even a slight green hue, some streaming bubbles, and fairly heavy lacing left on the glass. The aroma is of strong hop resin, pine, grapefruit, and white bread. The flavor is of all those elements, but to a lesser strength. Bitterness isn’t particularly strong, here. Mouthfeel is light to medium, and Lagunitas DayTime finishes mostly dry, a bit tart, and somewhat dull. RJT

12 oz. bottle from BevMo. Nose of grapefruit and light, floral hops. Citrus hops flavor with a dry, malty finish that checks the bitterness. This was poured into a pint glass. 
The appearance was a nice looking mostly clear yellow color with a light dose of small carbonation to be seen rising to fill a one finger white semi - foamy head that concaves nicely. 
The smell had a nice blended dose of sweet citrus to bright bitter pine with a little bit of orange as it warmed. 
The taste copied the smell just right rolling over my tongue in a sweet sticky way. There was a nice sweet sticky citrus aftertaste that lead into a sweet refreshing finish. 
On the palate, this one sat fairly light and came across pretty sessionable. The carbonation was good for the style and for me as it had enough prickliness but held back just enough to make a great session. 
Overall, well how about that. At 4.65 and a Summer seasonal that held up until now. I should would bang this again and can only imagine what it’s like fresh.

bit of a floral aroma. Very tasty seems light in in taste and the body is rather thin. Seems more of a summer ale and although it is an IPA seems a little on the weak side. Yet a very refreshing enjoyable brew.

the more I drink this, the more I realize how balanced the resinous hop flavors and malts are - nothing bitter, nothing too ’caramelly’ just a straight forward, light, but resinous brew>>> aroma isn’t big - some nice pine and tangerine aromas with a bit of earthiness - flavor a bit bigger with some nice depth - smooth dry pine, mango jam, and some light toasty malt sweetness - very low bitterness, no dankness - just smooth and very well balanced with a nice sappy hop background - follow up a more bitter brew with this and itll surprise you...
Light yellow pour with full nose of grapefruit. Nice bitter taste. Med carbonation with bitter aftertaste. A little thin but to be expected for the abv. Well above average session.
12 oz bottle from Giant Eagle in Pittsburgh. has a nice sweet taste without being over burdened with hops. Smooth and creamy. Very good overall.
Bottle. Pale yellow with small pff-white foamy head, sharp hops aroma, medium carbonation, hoppy taste with floral flavor, hint of citrus, long finish. Very nice brew.

Transfer from BA review on 5-12-14-

 Poured from bottle into a pint glass

 Appearance – The beer pours a clear golden yellow color with a one finger head of white foam. Tons of carbonation bubbles can be seen streaming up through the brew. The head fades over a moderate amount of time leaving a fantastic level of foamy rings of lace on the sides of the glass.

 Smell – For a session IPA, the aroma of the beer surprisingly heavy on the grapefruit hop smell. Along with the more bitter grapefruit are some other aromas of a tangerine and mango sweetness with a little bit of a grassy and cracker aroma as well Overall the aroma is rather nice. 

 Taste – The taste begins with a smooth bready flavor mixed with a little bit of a grapefruit hop taste. As the taste advances the breadiness remains as a base for the brew, with it being joined later on by a little bit of a grainy taste toward the end. All the while the little bit of orange and caramel flavor that are present upfront seem to intensify in nature as the flavor moves on to the end. Later on in the taste, as the grapefruit hop increases a bit in intensity, other flavors of a lemongrass and a light floral hop taste come to the tongue. With these new found hop flavors and the nice increase in the sweeter and malty flavors of the brew, a very smooth, yet moderately hopped and enjoyable flavor is left to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel – For an only 4.6 % abv brew, the body of the beer is on the thicker side with a carbonation level that is on the lower side. While normally a lighter body and very high carbonation would be better for the session style, for amplifying the malt and the hop the slightly thicker (at least for a 4.6 % abv.) and lower carbonation do the brew nicely and really make this a nice session IPA.

 Overall – This is so far the best session IPA that I have had. Unlike most session IPA, it has a degree of balance due to a more malty and sweet presence and doesn’t taste like I am drinking hops mixed with water. This was very enjoyable session IPA and one I would certainly recommend.

NightTime...DayTime! Nightime...DayTime!

That won’t make any sense to you if you haven’t seen the BBC America Animal specials. On to the review.

Bottle. 

A: Cloudy gold with a white cloud head. Lacing. 

N: Grapefruit, spruce, biscuit and cracker. Blood oranges and earth. Leafy. Not an overly complex nose, but it sure is nice. 

T: Quiet bitterness that evolves into something needling. Light malt base. 

M: Sharp carbonation, light body. No alcohol as one would hope. 

O: Lagunitas continues to give us solid, enjoyable beer. I mean, this could be closer to Sucks, but all their IPAs could. (And that’s not really a fair comparison given the malt/hop bill differences.)
Bottle, pours a bubbly golden. Nice earthy hop aroma. Grassy, resinous, and citrus hops. A very drinkable session IPA.

pours a slightly hazy pale yellow with a lasting bubbly white head and spotty lacing. hints of pine and lemon and grain in an otherwise subtle aroma. mouthfeel is medium thin but crisp. taste has lemon, mineral, and butterscotch notes. finish is muted but minerally.

Bottle. Clear pale gold with a thick rocky white head. Aroma is almost entirely pine and earth with a light lemon underpinning. Taste still has a huge pine factor but the citrus comes out a lot more with hints of grapefruit, tangerine and orange. Not much of a maul presence. Medium creamy mouthfeel with a little carbonation on the tip of the tongue. This packs a ton of flavor and aroma for a session beer.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a goblet. It was bottled on 7/23/14 and cost $3.20 ($0.27 per ounce).



Appearance: Pale lager-like white gold hue over a mostly clear body. Spastic effervescence clearly visible. Pours to a three-finger, white, fluffy head that retains and laces extremely well.



Smell: Huge dank resin and tropical fruit juice concentrate. Very sweet and inviting.



Taste: There seems to be a formula to the “Session IPA,” yet some breweries hit it out of the park and others strike out. Lagunitas DayTime is definitely is one of the former as it has both great taste and complexity – qualities you don’t tend to get in a small brew like this.



Many session IPAs tend to taste like hoppy water, but this one has a genuine malt foundation to it. Light, pilsner-like malts with just a hint of smokiness or bready character. The hops are quite prominent to say the least. A strong spicy sensation at first with herbal characteristics. They transition to something earthier, like pine needles through the middle and finish with a classic lemony citrusy flavor on the finish. Usually, this type of palette would grow old quick, but in this case it works perfectly.



Drinkability: This beer does exactly what it’s supposed to do: deliver big flavor while still being refreshing and sessionable. The mouthfeel is thin and crisp, but always smooth going down and leaves nary an aftertaste (maybe a hint of lemon peel). At 4.65% ABV it’s definitely in the session-able range for most people, though considering how good it tastes and easy it drinks, I doubt many people will have a problem throwing back a few of these (if only it came in cans!).

355 mL bottle. Nice looking beer. Hops are a balance of citrus and pine. Not sweet. Dcent mouthfeel for the style. Better than, say, Stone Go To. Just need to up the hop flavour a touch, while avoiding the all-pine solution that so many of these session IPAs use.

(bottle - 12 oz) Hazy gold with a white head. Pine resin and peppery hops in the aroma. Grassy and citrusy at the start with kind of a grapefruit and flower combo. Quickly dries out to a very bitter and astringent finish.

Poured from a 12oz bottle a very light golden color with a pillowy head of small bubbles. Nice citrus hop aroma. Taste is very light with minimal bitterness. It's honestly a bit too thin and watery for my liking.

Hops, hops, and more hops when you put your nose to it, and it’s pungent. Pours a clear gold with a large white head. You can taste the musk on this one. It’s a medium bitter. It’s a light body with a sticky texture and a slight bitter finish.

355ml bottle from Saveur-biere



Pours pale yellow with a small head. Aroma of crisp malts, tropical fruits, pine, citrus and grass. Taste is crisp, hoppy and malty with loads of pine, buttery sweetness, citrus and grass. Finish is crisp, bitter and hoppy with some pine and resinous sweetness. Quite refreshing and piney hop bomb.

Bottle to half-pint glass (shared with the Mrs.). Looks good for the style; a mostly transparent gold with white head. Smells solid too; tropical and citrus hops with a touch of well-balanced sweetness from the malt. Tastes like it smells with a pleasantly light mouthfeel. Super-sessionable.  I like this one.

12oz bottle. Clear yellow color. Thin white head. Some loose bits of lace. Light to medium body. Smooth, kind of crisp, lighter carbonation. Light dry finish. There’s a certain slightly soft Lagunitas texture to the carbonation that gets a little getting used to, and a noticeably lighter body, but otherwise the texture is good. Good grassy hop, kind of zesty. Good mild clean bready malt. Moderate to bigger bitter taste, minimal sweet. More dry finish. Solid, lighter session IPA. A bit too light in body to substitute a full strength IPA though.

Bottle. No date on the bottle but fresh on the shelf this week and tastes fresher than I remember having it previously. And as always, freshness is a big deal with these session IPAs. Pours very light and clear, looks like a lager. Getting big punchy hops up front with light malt. Not harsh, bitter, or overly thin. I don’t love this style but I do enjoy both hops and afternoon beers so I keep coming back. This one does the job when it’s fresh like this.

Being English and heavily into the growing craft scene many foreign beers are compared with our national counterparts. This one has a doppelganger. It looks, smells, tastes and resembles Kernel Pale Ales. Very light lemon in colour with clean white head that dissapates rapidly (unlike Kernel). Citrus led aroma, with lemon and some grapefruit. Spicy pangs and some florals. Fresh and inviting if a little one-paced. Taste is more citrus and spicy, floral bitterness. Malt makes a cameo appearance in biscuit form. Light palate but does not faill into the oft-seen trap of becoming watery.

Poured into a shaker. Light gold color with a small white head. Aroma is very hop forward with lots of floral and citrus character. Flavor starts with some light biscuity malt and transitions into floral and citrusy hop notes. Nicely hopped and very fresh tasting. Medium-light body with crisp carbonation. Awesome for a lighter session IPA.

Pours a pale yellow, with light white head. The color of a bud or Coors light. Aroma is hoppy, light citrus notes and pine notes. Taste is grapefruit peel, citrus. Juicy body, with a somewhat dry and bitter finish. Light malts. Pretty good session beer!

It took me three different bottle openers to get the beer out of this, so it had better be good! (Harumph!) It (eventually) pours a pale yellow body, moderately bubbly, with a modest white head. There’s little trace of malt in the aroma and the hops come across in a zesty, citric, and (alas) cat box fashion. The flavor has a mild cereal and bread malt backbone with hop tastes reflective of the nose. There’s only a mild bitterness to it. The finish is a bit watery with a light lemon bitterness. Just okay.

Ins Glas ergießt sich ein strohgelbes Bier mit ordentlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch intensiv hopfig, grasig, tropische Früchte. Geschmack sehr fruchtig hopfig, bitter, grasig, tropische Früchte, leicht, süffig.
Light yellow with hoppy aroma. Clean malt taste up front. Light hops with a little bitterness in the finish. Nice session beer.

Pilsnery light gold. Good foamy head but disapates shortly with lace. Good aroma with stone fruit,citrus, maybe some sweet malts. Good taste kinda hoppy floral,citrus,,toast malts, grassy finish, citrus finish. Cleanish but not boring, has a classic Lagunitas taste in a lighter beer.

Poured a light gold, good head. Aroma is floral and citric hops. Flavor is light crackery malts followed by more floral and undefined citrus hops. Finishes a touch earthy. Sort of an American Bitter in my book. Nice.

355 ml bottle. No freshness info.

Pours clear pale golden color with large white head. Very nice floral hoppy aroma, pine needles, some gooseberry bush and lemony fruits. Lemony fruits on the flavor, a bit oily feel to it, resinous hops on the aftertaste. Very tasty and feels quite fresh.

3516
Citrusy caramel aroma. Lightly malty, mostly hoppy, semi-bitter flavor. Light-medium bodied with average bubbles. Certainly an above average session beer.

12oz bottle from Julio’s.

Appearance : Clear pale yellow with small head.


Aroma : Crisp and fresh floral hops. Light piny notes. Some malt. Fairly restrained overall but still some complexity.


Taste : Malt and floral hops. Minimal piny notes. Very light resinous notes. Finish dry floral hops with light bitterness and malt. 


Palate : Fairly lively carbonation. A bit softer would have made it better IMHO. Dry and thin mouthfeel. Not too thin but almost.


Overall : Quite sessionable but carbonation is a bit too strong to be quaffable. Nicely dry and refreshing. Nice floral hops. Not bad but could be a bit more complex and palate could be improved a bit. Still a nice drink, I’d have a second one.

This brew pours a clear straw color with a medium white head that evaporates steadily. Stringy lacing on the glass. Aroma of grassy hops, citrus and malt. Light-bodied with flavors of herbal hops, citrus and sweet malt. The finish is mildly bitter with a lingering citrusy hops aftertaste. Solid Session IPA all around.

Bottle. Pours a near clear light yellow with a slight gold hue with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a good amount of pine with some dankness and just a hint of onion with a light grain backing. Flavor has a dank onion note with some light grains and a hint of grass underlying.
A nice session IPA. I like what Lagunitas did here. However this offering does not stand up to their other products. That said, if I want a session IPA, I will definitely consider this one.
Bottle from Hazel’s beverage world. Golden color, white head. Bitter taste with citrus, hops, pine, resin and a bit of peach. Bitter finish with citrus, resin and peach. Excellent session IPA.

This is my second, and last, " session" ipa. To me insipid in all aspects of taste along with a rough unpleasant finish. Anyhow will save some bucks by just sipping a good ipa or apa

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Thanks southbierbro! Pours a bright pale yellow with a hint of haze with a white head. The smell is lemon, wort, hay, grass - fresh. The taste is lemon, grass, hay and wort as the smell indicated. Light in body with average carbonation. An easy drinker that has a fresh taste.

Thanks to John for sharing. Very floral
in the nose. Fresh and very dry. Nearly no sweetness. Dry, hoppy intense and floral with lots of citrus. The aftertaste is smooth, very dry, very bitter, floral and great! 13/12/12/13
12oz bottle. Pale golden color with one finger head. Grapefruit and citrus aroma. Lighter taste, but very drinkable. I enjoy this one.

Golden brew with lots of pine and cedar aroma. Taste is loaded with pine hops. So while it smells and tastes great it is thin and watery and for the low ABV it has the big ABV price. Had been looked at this one but had been turned away by the low alcohol content but then HEB finally pulled some packs to sell as singles.  Now I can say I tried it and yes it is good but still not something I will purchase again.

On tap at Beer Keyaki shared by Todd from Beercats. A clear light gold with a substantial foamy head & great lacing. Medium bodied. The taste is very bitter, piney, ascerbic but clean. A good session IPA for those who wants bitterness.  ---Lagunitas Daytime IPA 4.65% Bottle from CBB 605 yen. It has a great sweet floral/citrusy hop bouquet that is more my speed than the Soul Style IPA  from Green Flash. Light straw gold color to accompany a light verging on thin body. This falls prey to the session IPA trap of a body that is too light. The taste is sweet, fruits, herbacious hops and prickly piney bitter hops but well balanced. Tasty. As I continue drinking it the hops build up giving me pine bark & more fruitiness. Very promising in a sessionable ale. Was better the second time around from the bottle.

Pours a yellow-orange with a one finger white head with nice lacing. Aroma is of citrus, pine, cracker malts, light tropical fruits, and light dankness. Taste is similar to the with some light toasted malts. Has a medium body with a slightly creamy mouthfeel and a semi-moderately bitter, medium finish. Overall,a tasty, refreshing session IPA that is just a tad below Stone’s Go To.

Incredibly, incredibly impressed. I always thought a session IPA was oxymoronic. This totally proves me wrong. Completely solid, and <5% ABV to boot. Color me impressed!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Light, straw color with a white head. Aroma is slightly grassy and floral. Lightly hoppy and crisp, great summertime IPA.

Wife: 4.1
My idea. I speak. People mumble. They listened. Now you can get IPA flavor in a bottle without getting stupid drunk. You’re welcome.
Citrusy caramel aroma. Lightly malty, mostly hoppy, semi-bitter flavor. Light-medium bodied with average bubbles. Certainly an above average session beer.
Very drinkable. Good but light hop profile. Floral and citrus notes. Refreshing. Great for a hot day
Pours a clear golden yellow with light white head. Very floral on the nose, some pine and grapefruit too; all follow onto the palate, with the floral notes dominating. Finishes with hop resin.

[Bottle] Yellow in color with a small cap of white head. Floral and spice in the nose. Taste is of citrus, pine cones, tropical fruits and mild caramel. Nice mouthfeel and body for the style. Happy to see them brew this session beer.

Wow, this is an excellent session beer (4.6 ABV) with heaps of west coast hops that jump out of the glass before the first sip, beautifully balanced with a crisp, mouth cleansing finish. This may be my go-to beer poolside this summer!
Pine grapefruit aroma. Mild murkiness with yellow but touch of amber color. A fizzy head that fades quick. Classic IPA bitter and sour. Touch of grapefruit to taste that comes clean in the end.

Bottle. The look is very clear, yellow golden in color and has a decent white head. The smell is very fruity, nice, hops, pine, grapefruits, and pleasing. The taste is crisp, hops, fruits, pine, citrus, and good.

DayTime Ale is as drinkable a session IPA as you will find out there, in this newly crowded market. By no means is this a complex ale, it drinks very straightforward with a solid malt/hop balance and a medium bitterness. Well carbonated and balanced in all aspects. Would absolutely pick up another sixer of this with no hesitation.
Bottle. Clear yellow with a big, foamy white head. Aromas of pine, grass, biscuit, and lemon. Flavor is light pine, lemon, some earthiness, and biscuit. Light bodied, bitter finish.
Pours a pale golden color with a thick white head. Hop, citrus, floral, honey and malt aroma. Citrus, hop, floral, honey and malt flavors. Light body and average carbonation. Citrus hop finish.
12 oz bottle. Light gold and clear with a good sized white head. Aroma is of grass, light pine, a hint of garlic, and citrus. Taste is of citrus, pine, grass, and light onion.
Pours a very light amber color with a bready off white head. Notes of cat pee, and white grapefruit. Thin mouthfeel and clean finish.

Ap - 5 - super big billowy white head that sticks forever on this guy and leaves lots of lacing, clear straw colored beer. 
Ar - 7 - lemony, spicy, floral aroma coming from this one. 
T - 7 - bitter for sure, but mostly floral hops, with some lemon and peppery notes in there too. It reminds me of a homebrew recipe called cream of three crops, made with williammette and crystal. 
P - 4 - extra light, knocked it for losing significant malt backbone. Alc non-existant, aftertaste is floral, grassy hops
O - 3.75 - I’ll have to check the bottling date but its too floral and earthy, and also missing the malt backbone.

Julian code: 
079 4 1
6838 0640
It has a big hop nose, full of pine and grapefruit, but the taste falls short of the nose. Coats the tongue nicely with a light bitterness. I like it.

Nice floral hoppy grapefruit aroma. Flavor is light, almost slightly wheat beer like (this version was on cask), but very refreshing and solid for a session ipa. Maybe slightly prefer Founders all day ipa. Maybe slight watery palate so loses a point for that.

Does his skin fall off or something? I don’t want to replace the bedding. Just get him out. .. Gold amber .. Medium foam in your jacket .. . Hops: for your session pleasure .. . Why are you breathing on me?! .. . Easy and giddy to drink to drink to drink .. . A great example of this rising style .. . . Now, if you will excuse me, I have to not speak to you people any longer. Thank you.
Thin yellow pour, scant head. Pine and grapefruit in the nose. Bitter. Middle is soft grain. Bitter, medium finish. Good work.

Solid IPA -- there is so much flavor in it. Puts other session beers to shame with fully-formed hop flavors of grass, lemon, apricot and pine. Nice backing malts, not sweet and not dry, with a dusky day’s-work-done malt backbone.

Pours golden with white frothy head. Smell is grapefruit citrus hops. Taste is dry and quite hoppy flavored without huge bitterness or a syrupy sweet backbone. Like a hop tea. A bit earthy. Very easy drinking and flavorful. Perfect full body and very crisp carbonation. Good stuff.
12 oz bottle. Pours pilsner gold with a thick airy head. Pine, citrus, grass aroma. Very light mouthfeel. Mild bitterness, lemon. Soapy.

A- Pours a light yellow hue with a small head that fades quickly with some lacing.

S- Citrus, bready.

T- Floral, citrusey hops all the way through with a lingering hop bitterness.

M- Medium bodied and effervescent.

D- Amazingly drinkable. I will keep this in the normal rotation as a session beer.

Bottle at the hotel room in San Diego. Clear pale golden beer with a decent airy white head. Hoppy pine apple aroma, mango, grassy, citrus, floral, caramel, hay notes, some passion fruit. Hoppy floral flavor, pine apples, mango notes, grapes, some hay. Rather thin bodied, but apart from that it’s really nice.

RERATE: 6 pack bottle from Savor Market. Murky yellow pour with thin bright white head. Aroma is herbal, minty. Tastes are light resin citrus and solid floral hops. Drinkable. 7.2  -- 4/11/14: Think this was on tap at Proof... yellow gold pour. resiny, juicy, floral aroma. tastes are tropical fruit, herbal, little bitter, zesty. 7.0
Pours a pale yellow, with a thin, quickly fading head. A very floral aroma, with some citrus notes. Feels light bodied, with an almost pilsner quality. I’m not sure what a Fractional IPA is, though.

Slightly hazy greenish pale gold with a 1 finger, soapy to creamy off white head. Aroma is big on citrus hops, some light cereal and toasty malt, hints of tropical fruit, floral and grassy hops. Flavor is toasty Pale malt, light bready notes, a hint of berry fruit, acidic citrus hoppy twang and a little grassiness to the finish. Light body, spritzy carbonation, thin, slightly oily, but acidic feel. Good stuff overall, great aroma, but it sort of goes downhill from there.

Perfect session beer for me. Pours clear straw colour, with a white head, decent lacing. Aroma is resinous, grassy, melon. Light, crisp, easy drinking body. Taste is fairly hoppy but is balanced out well with a malt body. Really enjoyed this.

Really nice and hoppy with 4.65% alcohol. Awesome session beer! Light body, I could definitely drink a bunch of these!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This is an American pale ale w/ a strong emphasis on hops, even for the style. IT pours a slightly hazed orange golden w/ a small head of fine white bubbles. There is a slight touch of biscuit-like malt but this is really all about the hops, which is not a bad thing at all. It is juicy and full-flavored, esp. and finishes w/ just a touch of sweetness and citrus-rind bitterness. I have said it before and will say it again, I am really liking these dry, sub-5% ABV hop monsters, the thinking man’s IIPA.

飲みやすいIPA
かなり華やかで、飲みやすくまとまってる
万人受けしそう  
ラグニタスのIPAシリーズでは一番飲みやすく華やかかも

Aroma of ropey, resinous hops and honeydew melon. Light yellow, like a filtered wit. Starts bitter but quickly goes citrus sweet. The flavor of these light hoppy ales usually doesn’t follow through on the scent it seems. This is also very light bodied, while crisp enough to be refreshing and not a total wash. It’s good with dinner but if you like taking down a few beers of this strength you’d be better served by wheaty offerings.

Vintage: 2014
Appearance: Transparent Straw; Fluffy, White head; good lace; mid-range visible carbonation
Smell: Freshest of the fresh weed, Dank as all hell; lemon zest; faint pine; faint orange/tangerine
Taste: Weed, dank, dank weed; lemon; tangerine; lingering grasiness 
Mouth-feel: Medium carbonation; light body; resinous, dry finish 
Overall: Just wonderful! Fresh, clean, danky goodness. Perfect all-day beer!

12oz bottle 3/7/14 (Binny’s Plainfield Mix A Six)-40° in English Pint-Pours a clear golden with a small white head. Aroma of hops and malt. Taste of the same. This light bodied brew is well balanced and easy to drink. Great brew.
Bottle pours yellow with fluffy head. Aroma is big citrus and melon hops. Taste is tropical fruits with a really nice bitter finish. Could drink many
Six pack from Safeway in Redwood City, CA. Light lemon, brine, and mild pineapple flavors. Yes... the official beer for Getting Stranded On A Desert Island.
Light sessionable IPA. Some bitterness some hops some malt. Not a whole lot but kinda refreshing and drinkable.
Bottle. Clear, light yellow, frothy head. Medium to light body, strong pine, but not slick or overdone like many of the low alcohol IPA’s. Good for this style.

12 oz. bottle. Appearance: pale straw color, clear, small white head that diminishes quickly. Aroma: citrus and floral hops, light cereal. Palate: average carbonation, bitter lasting finish, sticky texture. Taste: very light front, builds in bitterness to fairly bitter finish. Overall, super drinkable, very light, still very flavorful.
12 oz bottle pours golden with a white head. Aroma of pine, citrus and malts. Taste is pine and malts.

Bottle from 99 Bottles (Federal Way, WA). Huge cat pissy hop nose, grass, tar, sweat, and insecticide. Very pale straw color. Fruity initial with citrus (lemon) / a slight sourness intrudes in mid palate / light bitter finish. Thin-medium body. Pretty damn good. A session IPA with really jacked up aroma and refreshing flavors.

12 oz bottle with date code 316 3. Pretty fresh. Pours clear golden, pretty light-colored, with a white head. Lots of tropical fruits on the nose. Not at all grainy like other light pales. Flavor is crisp, clean, fruity and a nice dry finish follows. This is one of the ultimate session beers. Delicious.

Clear amber, moderate head, decent lace/retention. Aroma is grapefruit, citrus, caramel, blah blah all the usual American stuff. Medium to light body, big aroma for what it is but that’s exactly what they wanted. Pretty nice.
Pale golden body with white head that leaves behind nice lacing. Herbal, pine and citrus aromas. Earthy, lightly malted body with spruce tip flavors. Refreshing and quite sessionable.

Such a light looking beer with a little more surprise than it appears at first. When I first poured it I thought to me, oh, it looks like a bud light. But, when I smelled it, I knew right away that this was something more. Looks can be very deceiving. It has a sweet sweet citrus, floral and hoppy aroma. The first taste I took, I actually thought that I wasn’t going to enjoy it. After the second and third sip it started to grow on me. It has a mix of hops flavor, but not a lot of the bitter flavors that accompanies hoppy beers. Its a smooth, thirst quenching ale from the front all the way through the finish. It hits every aspect of your tongue all at once. Citrus, floral and hoppy flavors stay with you for a minuet after you swallow. Its a pretty good golden ale. Something that can relax you at the end of a long day, just as the description says. I could drink a few of these with no problem. I enjoyed this smooth ale, and I would recommend it to many.

12 oz
Wow... Very strong and hoppy aroma with herbal, floral and weedy elements. Has the power of a double IPA. The flavor packs plenty of hops but is, of course, not as intense as the aroma suggests...not as bitter, having only a mild bitterness. Also a bit more fruity.

O: extraordinary version of a session ipa, with plenty of flavor and a remarkably full and strong aroma.
Best of this specific style (so far). Would earn a higher rating but for my preference for a fruitier hop mix.
Draft - Grassy, lemon hops with a light sweetness. Pale gold with a rich white head. Fresh leafy hops, citrus and grass again. Refreshing and light, very nice.

Pours a pale straw with a head that gets flimsy pretty fast. Aroma is pleasant (maybe my favorite feature): hay, hops are floral/herbs, some cheese. Taste is weighted towards sour and bitter. Palate is really watery and thin but refreshing. It’s a good beer. Highly drinkable but not worthy of some of the 4.0+ ratings I read.

12oz into a glas in vegas. Pours a lemon pepper yellow. aroma is also lemon pepper, hops and tart dessert. Taste is fresh and hopful, danity hops prevail all over, freshness is superiir, taste is like new, wow, just wow, what a great session ipa, the best ive ever had. So solid. Lauunitas never dissapoints,

Wow!! Another amazing IPA by Lagunitas. Excellent hoppy resinous aroma. Taste is so so crisp and clean and smooth with lots of carbonation and no bitterness. So easy to drink. Very happy flavor with a bit of malt to even things out. Clear yellow color.

The gold standard for session IPAs. Rich hoppy nose - I actually preferred the nose to Lagunitas Sucks’, tasted on the same evening - with a balanced hop flavor. Best of all is the ABV - enjoy a 6-pack while watching the game and you’ll have a way better time than your Bud Light buddies (though they might feel better the next morning).

12oz bottle poured into my ipa glass. Pours a clear straw yellow color with a medium whit head that leaves light lacing. Smells of pine, citrus and resin. Tastes of the same things in the smell with a good hop presence. Mouthfeel is light with good carbonation. Great flavor for a session ipa on the same level as All day ipa from Founders but with more of a west coast infuence. Great beer.
A golden beer with a small white head. The aroma is big on citrus, some pine, and yeast. The flavor is lemon and pine with a little funk in the finish.

12 oz bottle. Pours a hazy lemon yellow color with a foamy white head. Some lacing. Aroma of citrus rinds, hint of pine, and lemongrass. Very crisp and refreshing. The perfect session ale! Taste of lemon and orange zest, pine, grass, and some wheat. Not a fan of pale ales, but I am loving this!

Clear yellow pour with fair white ring of head. Very nice and sessionable apa. All the Big "C" hops are there. Pretty much a classic or the style. Big citrus and foresty hops. Bitterness with bite, but not really overpowering at all. A very solid APA.

Aroma: sweet malty/hoppy aroma , light notes

Taste: sweet malty taste, pleasant full mouth bitter finish

Appearance:copper color thin lace head


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from Lazy Dog. Pours a pale transparent gold with very slight cream colored head. Aroma of slight citrus and grasses. Taste of slight floral hops and citrus with moderate carbonation.

Shared 12 oz. bottle at John’s Buffet in Winfield, IL., and poured to fluted glassware showing a light gold, nearly straw color, with some fluffy to bubbly, white head foam, and spotty lacing. The nose was pungent & expressive white grapefruit, with some breadiness lightly backing it up. Light to medium bodied, with suitable carbonation, and medium expression to the rindy & citrusy hop bitterness. With some finishing dryness, a decent, palate cleansing APA.

12 oz bottle from United Liquors (New Lenox, IL). I’ve been buying so much All Day, I figured I may as well try the competition. Pours a pale golden straww hue, lively carbonation through the body with frothy whitish head atop, dies to a mellow layer, sits atop small and laces ok. Mellow, brighter whiteness. a gentle golden honey hazed glow. Aromas are big juicy citrus rind and juice, lemon and bigger grapefruit vibe, rind oils, touches of florals, more lemonhead and gentle melon. Faint white grape, bready malt, gentle gumball and tropical fruit waft into more big grapefruit juice. A bit bready, grainy, but very assertive citrus hop presence is quite nice and fresh. Initial is lighter end of the fold showing more melon, fruit and decent citrus kick. Some lemon, kaffir lime and oranges. Some bready malt, white grape, and bready malts. Straw, some grainy cereal elements. Middle is a bit more citrusy, lemony and floral, touches of grass, more melon and some fruity elements. A bit more bready, fainy waft toasty as we move back. The hop bitterness seems to kick in a bit more. Some dryness, medium to decent bitterness. A bit of rind element, decent hopping hits the palate as we start to finish. Nice stuff, fresh, a bit fruity. The nose preaches some really strong citrus elements but tapers out into the beer itself which while still very approachable with a smaller body, is a touch sweet and fruity at times and not necessarily the bitter kick my palate looks for. Still that said this might be up others alley much more. Solid stuff, I’ll stick with All Day though.

On cask at Mr. Goodbar in Buffalo, NY. Oh my, this is tasty. Super citrusy...smells distinctly like orange peel with a hint of grapefruit. A friend says he hates grapefruit but this smells superb. Really light a big hop wallop. Great taste and depth of flavor given the low ABV. A home run for Lagunitas for sure.
Pours a clear yellow on tap with thin white head. Aroma of lemon and orange with a sweet fruitiness. Taste follows, like a sweet soapy citrus flavor. Meh, not for me.
Aroma is dry pine and grassy hops. The flavor is citrus, light grapefruit, fruit, mild sugar sweetness, a hint of hop resin and a mild/medium grassy/bitter finish.

Pours clear bright straw golden, big fluffy white head.

Smell crisp, fresh cut grass, bit of citrus

Taste dirty earthy citrus and hop

Very light and crisp

Great session ipa

Bottle, Wine Warehouse, CHO.

Pours very light golden with a sewage froth head. Smells very yummy: strong hops - very pine rather than grapefruit. Tastes of lemon, pine, and water. A bit thin.

12 oz. bottle from my buddies Mike and Rachel- thanks for letting me steal this one from your fridge! Pours a clear, bright, pale gold with a small white head and lots of bubbles. The aroma begins with a burst of lemon citrus, then shows grass and herbs, and some balancing pale malts. The flavor is equally bright and lemony, with grass, herbs, and pale malts. Light-bodied, with medium-high carbonation and a crisp, dry, almost tart mouthfeel. Really nice session APA.

Short, 12oz bottle. Clear, yellow color. White choppy foam. Aroma of those seductive Lagunitas hops oils. Very thin body. Light flavor, low ABV. Flavor of light pale malt syrup, resin hops. Thin flavor, not much left on the palate. This is the ultimate session ale. (3882)

Draft @ Lucky Pie Pizza and Tap House, Denver, CO. Pours a hazy yellow color with a white head. Has a fruity dry hoppy citrus aroma. Fruity malty citrus hoppy flavor. Has a fruity malty citrus hoppy finish.

Bottle; poured a clear dull gold with a whitish head. Aroma was funky hoppy. Pine, earth, stank, citrus and Forrest. Light palate, lot of hops that linger off and on. Aggressive, but not great flavor.

Clear light yellow body with a tall, long lasting white head.
Fresh Spruce aroma.
The flavor carries light resiny bitterness with a supportive sweetness. Light bodied without seeming watery. The best of these session pale ales that I’ve tried so far.

Pours a clear golden yellow color with a small white head. Aroma is citrus hops, lemon, orange rind, and grapefruit. The taste is resiny with a lightly bready malt backbone and some grapefruit. It’s really good. Especially considering it’s low abv.

12 oz bottle at Bogeys in Leawood, Kansas. The pour is mostly clear golden yellow with a one inch white head. The aroma is lemon citrus, a bit of grass resin, and a light sweetness. The taste is the lemon citrus, the grass, all balanced upon a faint cracker malt base. Certainly hop forward. The palate is light bodied, active carbonation, and a dry slightly sweet grassy finish. Easy drinking.

Sampled at GABF 2013. Gold with a white head. Fresh citrus hop, pine and toasted malt aroma. Similar flavor, medium bitterness and light sweetness. Light body with a thin feel and a refreshing finish.

Bottle pour..light golden color small head that dissipates ..not much active carbonation..nose is wet grass with a hoppy citrus lemon lime in there as well.mouthfeel is quite light bodied with a spritzy mouthfeel..quite dry finish that has some lemon lime seltzer qualities..not a big fan..

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Wegmans Leesburg. It pours a clear lighter gold with a rocky white head. The nose has nice dank herbals with a touch of citrus and tropical fruit. Fairly light on the tongue with a solid hop presence and just a hint of balancing sweetness. Crisp and highly sessionable with a dry finish. Nice daily drinker.
Pours a nice gold color, white head. Tons of tropical fruit, lychee, grapefruit, resin. Very nice.

18th April 2013
Lightly hazy gold beer with a little white head. Palate is light and crisp. Mild minerals. A light fruity citrus, touch of pine and a whisper of skunk. Fairly neutral malt underneath. Light minty aftertaste and vibe. Light and refreshing.

Bottle shared with iphonephan. Pours clear pale golden with a small off white head. Aroma of grapefruit,citrus, tropical fruits. Flavour is light to moderate sweet and over moderate bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Aroma is somewhat piney and fruity. Grapefruit and mango. Appears light a light beer straw yellow. White head good lacing. Taste is hoppy but grassy a tad. Very crisp with quick bitterness. Grapefruit and apricot.

Bottle from Beer Run. The pour’s light gold with a modest white head. The nose is pleasant lemon sherbet, a bit of wood. angel food cake. The taste is sweet, moderately bitter. Soft lemon. Grapefruit. Bright zippy citrus. A touch of white bread. Really light, refreshing. Light body, moderate carbonation. Overall, yep, this delivers.
Bottle->SA. Clear lite gold with big frothy white head. A: strong pine hops, resin, grass, citrus. T: pine and grapefruit hops, wetgrass. Light and crisp palate. Lingering bitterness. Pretty good.

12oz bottle. Pours a clear straw color with a fluffy white head and nice lacing. Very tropical nose, with mango, peach , grass, grapefruit and pine. Taste is piney, grassy and grapefruit. Light body, smooth, medium carb with a very dry finish.

Fresh, fruity, hop aroma. Notes of pine also. Super pale yellow. Billowy white head. Sweet malt first, Hints of sourness in background. Nice mild bitternss at first but kicks up nicely on the finish. I like balance in APA’s and this doesn’t disappoint. I prefer a little more malty bite...but good.
what a wonderful change of pace... all the aroma(tropical fruits, strawberries, pine, etc) and most of the flavor of a great ipa in session form.

Pours a clear slightly orange yellow with a few fingers of stark white foam. Slightly sweet, floral hops in the nose. Some light fruit in the flavor, hint of apricot, that fades into a light bitterness. Very nice, easy to drink session beer.

12 oz. bottle. Bright golden pour with a nice white head. Rich, pine and resiny hop aroma, with touches of grass. Light, flavorful, with strong pine hops. Light bodied, lively carbonation. Finishes dry and lovely. A very nice, light IPA. One of my favorite styles.
Nice ipa. Pours a golden yellow. Great hop aroma grapefruit and pine. Slightly bitter. Nice head. Nice beer.

The nose starts with a big, juicy citrus hop blast with some underlying pine notes. The starts with plenty of grapefruit and orange zest. The malt character is very light, grainy and crackery at best. As it warms, once again, the bitter, slighty resinous "greener" and grassier hops add to the flavor profile. A little thin, but very tasty.

Bottle. Pours a very light golden with minimal lacing. Aroma of pine. Taste of grapefruit, pine, and hints of citrus. Very good session IPA 

----Hophaze out
Poured from a 12 ounce bottle. Notes of citrus, grainy, malty, pine, slightly skunked. I really enjoy hoppy session beers, I would like this more fresh.

12oz bottle. Pours a clear light yellow color with two fingers of white head. Aroma is hoppy, citrus/tangerine, earthy, with a nice malt backbone.
Taste is piney, citrus (lemon, orange, grapfruit, tangerine), and pale matls.

Poured on draft. Pours a hazy yellow with a white head. Aroma is very citrusy and lemony with just a sweet malty backbone. Taste’s kind of like somebody put some lemon zest in here. Fruity and just slightly bitter. It would be good on a hot day.

Pours clear light-gold, actively effervescent, ample white head. Aroma is citrus and light yeast. Flavor is same. Palate has malt substance with a nicely bitter finish. Overall, a very nice beer. The concept of a refreshing, crisp beer that has an ABV that doesnt dictate the rest of your day. Also best drunk cold, fresh and with a thirst - left to linger, the beer shifts towards skunky.

12oz bottle, golden pour, small white head.  Excellent aroma and taste of hops, (lighlty done), but still satisified many hop heads out there.  Well balanced, toast, lively, slight bitter finish.  Could definitely drink many of these in one sitting.

Bottle. Pours a clear light yellow color with fizzy white head.  Aroma is grassy and lemon zest and some pale malt.  Taste is light lemon citrus, touches of grassiness, and crisp bready malts.  Dry finish.

Bottle at home with my dad. Pour is clear golden straw color with a small white head and great lacing. Grassy, lemony, slightly herbal, biscuity, straw, hay, weed, and citrusy aroma. Taste is citrusy, lemon peel, biscuity, spicy, wet dog, grass, weed, and stake bread with a light bitter finish. Thin body with high carbonation. Starts to taste a bit watered down as it warms, but a pretty nice seasionable beer - this one should be nice for the summer time.

Pours a very clear, light golden color with a nearly white, short head. Very grape fruity citrus nose. Wet, medium-bodied mouthfeel. Finishes with a little mild carbonation scrub. Grapefruit from start to finish. A little juicy at the end. This brew is in my wheelhouse. Love it!!
Bottle pour.  My dog helped me drink this at 3 in the afternoon.  Good hops - similar to Founders All Day IPA
bottle. Golden with small head. Light bodied IPA with excellent hops. Slightly fruity. Pretty good easy drinking beer.

Bottle.  Pours clear gold with a medium, two finger frothy and bubbly white head, short retention with the lacing retreating to the glass edge, leaving good lacing.  Aroma is fresh grassy, pine, and citrus hops, lightly dank notes, peach and pear fruity esters, and light cracker malt.  Flavor is heavy hops and moderate bitterness, fruity esters, supporting malt and a dry finish.  Medium-light body and medium carbonation.
