It pours the same yellow gold as American adjunct lagers, maybe just a shade darker.  There’s no real head, no lace, and not much to distinguish the presentation.  The smell is actually slightly bad.  It reminds me of babyfood peas.  The taste is a little bit better.  It’s like someone figured out a way to hop water.  There is no real flavor other than the hops, and the twang at the finish of the sip is kinda beer-like, but I won’t have this again.  It’s not aimed at me, anyway.

Classic citrus and pine nose. First off I get that this is a session beer, but while very drinkable I just don’t think it is anything special. Balanced yes but muted also. Could drink many of these? Yes . Would I want to? No

Bottle from Yamaichi. Clear bright golden with a low head. Clean, soft citrus hop nose, lemon, grapefruit. Light toasty malt,mnice hop flavors, grapefruit sorbet, very clean, nicely bitter finish. Very well made to do as designed, be a light and refreshing seesion beer. Good stuff.

Not a big fan of this session beer trend. However, this is the best version I've found. Floral hoppy flavors (along with the aroma which initially is great) quickly dissipate and the body is thin. I'm sure I could drink a bunch in a row. Not sure I'd want to.

Bottle. Pale yellow color. Thin white foamy head. Aroma of flowers and esters, with a bit of citrus and clove. Flavor was lightly hopped, but clearly defined in its spice and pine layers. Not overpowering. I see what they were getting at with this brew. It works well for me, as I do not like too much hops. Light body, but not too light on flavor. If you love hops, this is weak, if you just like hop flavor, but not the kick in the face, this one is for you.

Bottle sample at a tasting at LiBira Pub in Haifa. Thanks DSG. Pours yellow with a nice head, aroma of litchi, orange, onion, lemon, flavor is slightly bitter with lemon grass, light fruits, melon, refreshing with some herbal hops, medium bodied, nice
12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $0.99 Very good!

355ml bottle. Clear gold colour, moderate white head. Looks more like a decent lager than an IPA. Aroma holds up to full strength IPAs, pine, grapefruit and a little grass clippings. Taste is lighter than the smell, the hops are there but don’t really come in until the end. Body is on the watery side. Overall, if light IPA was a thing, this would be a good one. Depends on if you think that is a good idea.

Strong aroma of lilles and grapefruit, approaching that of pine needles, despite it being several months old. Clear amber, medium head, sticky lacing. Nice floral hoppping with just light citrus compliment. Lillies in the finish. Light mouthfeel. Immensely sessionable, quaffable, and flavorful. Fantastic crafting.

12oz bottle poured into a Shaker at 38°.  Color is a bright pale gold with good carbonation and a fizzy head.  Aroma is a big citric hop scent.  It has a lighter medium body with a crisp mouth feel.  Flavor is just hops, big fruity citrus and pine.  After is more citrus and some bitterness.  Overall, its not the best, the citrus overpowers everything.
From notes. Bottle poured into a shaker. Light and summery. Citrus and pine hops. Pretty decent.

Lightly hazed straw colour, with a nice bubbly cap. Aroma of lemon citrus and pine. Taste is lemony and a sharp tart/short bitterness with a refreshing finish like lemoned sparkling water, but better. A delicious take on a sessionable ipa, but why would I drink this over other Lag ipa's?
Good session beer. Very drinkable. Citrus notes come through. I still prefer the Sumpin’ but this is a good alternative for all day drinking. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Body is a crystal clear light gold and holds up a massive head of sudsy white small bubbles.  Aromas are thick with lemon peel and cat pee... Cascade?  Flavor is a little washed out, but has a decent amount of hoppy wonderfulness.  It could have just a bit more residual sugar to help balance against the hop tea nature that it takes on, but I’d drink another.
Looks like a pilsner, but tastes amazing.  Shocked by how much flavor was packed into such a low ABV for an IPA.  Huge grassy and citrusy hops.  Love it!

On cask at Hay Merchant. Pours a cloudy gold with thick creamy white head leaving sticky lacing. The aroma is a potent floral hop and citrus with pine. Thin mouthfeel with light citrus and a bit watery in the finish. A good IPA from Lagunitas.
On tap.  Comes a clear light gold with a small white head.  Aroma of citrus, and florals.  Taste is lemons, oranges, grapefruit, malt, florals, and yeast.  Light and easy to drink.

Gold, clear, white head. Grainy malt with a little caramel. coarse resiny hops, finishes grainy with some citrusy zing. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a clear yellow with a small white head. Aroma of citrus hops and some light fruit. Flavor of citrus and fruit as well. Decent amount of hops in the finish.

Pours yellow with a really nice hop aroma.  Great hop flavor but finishes a little watery.  Great session ipa. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Fruity nose, full flavor with some nice hoppy elements, light and crisp. Love this beer and hope it is a mainstay.

Poured from 12oz bottle, pours a very clear light yellow with a thin head, doesn’t looke like an ipa by any means, aroma has a nicew amount of fruit and hops, the flavor has a nice crisp front end with a citrus finish, seems a little musty, probably been sitting on the shelf a little while, still pretty enjoyable.

Pours a nice dark straw golden color.  Nice one finger frothy white head, looks very much like a macro lager.  However the hops roll off this beer before you even move it toward your face.  Big citrus smell, tropical fruit. Grapefruit smell, slight orange peel with sweet mango type smell.  Slight pine smell.  Great carbonation, really opens up your palate.  Very nice taste, at the front  lemony and through the middle there is a definite orange peel and slight grapefruit.  Slightly bitter through the middle of the palate, finishes very nice, slight mango taste at the end.  Very decent mouthfeel for a 4.65%abv beer.  Very enjoyable, this would be a fantastic session IPA.

Bottle shared at a tasting at LiBira Pub in Haifa. Clear pale golden. Great hoppy aroma of tropical fruits (a lot of lychee). Rather dry flavor with nice fruity hops and refreshing mild bitterness in the finish. Medium-bodied. Very refreshing.

Bottle from MSM, tap at WB. Clear, lemon yellow pour with a short, brief white headeaving minimal lace. Nose is citrus. Light body, moderate carbonation. Tangerine, lemon, light toast and orange zest. Finish is short, lightly citrus bitter and dry. Fairly uninvolving. Maybe decent as an APA, but significant shortcomings as an IPA.
At a tasting, thanks DSG, no head, a touch hazy lightish yellow colour, aroma of lychee, apricot and some citrus, flavour of lychee, melon and caraway, bitterness just a touch coarse. A good IPA.

12oz bottle. Clear yellow with a foamy white head. Aroma of citrus, floral and some light cereal grains. Flavor of bitter hops, faint cereal malt and clean yeast profile. Light body with a thin mouth feel. Good session beer but of course any beer like this is going to be thin and watery.
Almost clear with nice foamy head. Aroma of hops and balance, tropical fruit. Taste of light bitterness, fruity hops, very light body. Refreshing with light palate.

Bottle from Todd, thanks!  Inactive hazy straw yellow with a thin white cap.  Aroma is dank and skunky with pale malts and floral hops.  Taste is overly skunked with floral and noble hops and mild herbal notes.  Finishes up mildly bitter.  Lagunitas makes some really good beers but this one is a bit of a drain pour.
On tap at Black Bottle on 12/22. Pours a golden color with white head.  Citra, hoppy, grapefruit flavors.  Nice, very light-bodied IPA.
12oz Draft A - Pours straw with a white frothy head. S - Lemon grass/resin nose T - Light biscuit, crisp grapefriuty hop. M - Light bodied, clean, crisp hop mouth feel. O - Sessionalbe IPA?/Lager

355ml bottle pours a bright golden color with a 2 finger white head that leaves some really nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma is very pleasant with some citrus and grass with a hint of grains.  Taste is citrus and grass hop bitterness with an underlying malty sweetness.  Medium bodied with some nice carbonation leaving a nice tickle on the palate.  Definitely a brew with some high quality ingredients and highly recommended.

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a pale yellow color with a huge soapy yellow-white head that lingered and left decent lacing. The aroma was pine, grapefruit, catbox, more pine and resin. the flavor was tangy and sweetish bread, pine and resin. Medium length sweet pine and resin finish. Medium body. Ok.

Bottle. Clear light amber color with ivory sheen. Dank skunk cabbage, spicy, cat spray, earthy, grassy hop aromas. medium body with a smooth mouthfeel. Spicy, fruity, pine hop flavors with a pale malt base--a bit light on the flavor side but still good.

Bottle. Pours a clear light yellow color with a nice fizzy head Grassy aroma with some lemon zest. Some hops in there as well. Really light taste with some hops and a dry finish. Very delightful. Not as potent as other Lagunitas beers, but a very good brew.

Tap @ Black Bottle Fort Collins. Pours a clear golden appearance worn an off white head. Spicy, light onion, herbal hoppy, lemon citrusy aroma. Fairly light, lemon, a bit floral, herbal flavor. A bit bland and watery.
light golden color. Looks like pee in a glass. Frothy white head.  Very heady nose of fresh bag of weed, tropical fruit, grass, oats, light hoppy body. Heady, very enjoyable. Moderate bitter finish.
12oz bottle-tight retaining white-yellow.  A-lemon/orange zest, then floral as it warms.  T-dry biting floral, lemon zest, some lt malt.  9/4/5/3/12-3.3 Another day, another bottle 9/4/7/4/13=3.7

A golden IPA with a thin off white head. In aroma, intense piney and meaty hops, rose water perfume, very nice. In mouth, a  nice crisp malt with piney hops, nice and balanced. On tap at Snallygaster DC, Oct. 13 2012.

Bottle:  The aroma is a nice combination of mango, melon, pine, floral notes, and a touch of lemon peel.  It pours a transparent gold with a one finger white head that fades to a thin film within a minute or so.  There is some spotty lacing left on the sides of the glass.The flavor starts with a good dose of mango and melon.  The finish has moderate pine with light lemon and some floral notes.  It’s light bodied with soft carbonation and mouthfeel.  Overall, a very easy drinking IPA.  I’ll be picking up more than just a single the next time I see it.

Location: 12 oz bottle a friend grabbed for me at some store in Florida, 12/18/12




Aroma: The nose is fruity hops, with some grapefruit, and some other tropical and citrus fruits.  
Beyond that there’s some light toasted malts, and some pine/resin hops as well.


Appearance: It pours a slightly unclear golden-orange color with a rim of white head and light lace


Flavor: The taste has a clean bitterness and a good, though on the light side, sweetness for balance


Palate: It drinks lighter, though not watery at all, with a clean feel, average carb, and tons of drinkability


Overall Impression: 
I was quite excited for this one when it came out, but then I couldn’t find it anywhere, so big thanks to Jordan who saw this in a store over his Thanksgiving trip to Florida and grabbed me one!!  Beyond that, this one really delivers what it promises.  It really is a clean, easy drinking, session IPA.  It turned out great, and I was excited the hops weren’t dead, because I don’t know how long this bottle sat on the shelf, but it must have been a while, because it was purchased in the end of November.  Anyway, I could drink a ton of this.  Leave it to Lagunitas to basically invent and master the Light IPA style.  I really have no complaints other then the scarcity.  Put this in a can and sell it in 6 packs for about $8 and this would be a perfect beach/tailgate beer.

On tap at Fat Heads Pittsburgh. Pours a clear light yellow with a small white head. Aroma of super grassy and garlicky hops, some pot too.  Flavor Of sweet pot with garlicky hops in the finish. Light, bitter, and hoppy. Good stuff!
8/4/8/4/14 (3.8/5)

On tap at Tyler’s, Durham. Great to see so many quality craft breweries putting thought into well-balanced session beers, and this is one of the finer examples. Nice light orange pour, billowy carbonation. Dry hops and citrus in the nose, giving an impression of overall crispness. Certainly borne out in the light, elegant flavors. Plenty of depth and complexity though, all the traits of an IPA at sub-5%. Kudos.
Pours a light, amber color with a white head. Aroma is of citrus and pine hops. Flavor is earthy as well with the virus and pine. Overall pretty good.
On draft at Fatheads.  Poured clear gold with thin white head.  Floral, grassy nose.  Sharp citrus hop bite with piney notes.  Thin to medium bodied.  Well done.

12 oz bottle, Whole Foods Columbus.  Straw color with a medium, white, frothy head; head dissipates into a ring quickly but leaves plenty of lacing, and head is revived easily with swirling.  Aroma massively grapefruit and pine.  Flavor... boy, this is an odd one... taste is instant pineapple; then, grapefruit, pine, lemon, oregano, possibly juniper.  Palate medium-thin but quite frothy in the mouth.  Surprising amount of flavor for the low level of alcohol.  Maybe a few more of these and I could rate this higher a point or two higher, but it’s just so unusual that I’m struggling with that.  That said, a beer like this at 4.65% abv really makes me wonder why Bud Light exists.

I love everything about this beer.  It’s just a flawless, fresh, bottled IPA to consume on a day off, one after another.  I love it’s ABV.  Great mouthfeel.  Excellent malt backbone.  Tasty, lemony hops.  Big Hops.  Please make more.

Bottle.   Poured light golden color with a frothy big head.  Very  nice and fresh aroma of hops, grapefruit citrus.  Mmmm, nice fresh taste too.  some bubble gum, pineapple notes, grapefruit, with light but sound malt backbone notes.  Well done.
On draft, straw yellow pour, citrus and resiny hops in the aroma.  Taste is similar with a toasted malt profile.  Good stuff!
light gold pour, white head, slightly cloudy - strong hop (pine/grapefruit) aroma - lemon/pine/grapefruit on the tongue with little malt - finishes grapefruit
Draft. Pours gold with a white head. Fresh citric hops, almost tropical, with floral and piney notes, and a light pale malty base. Good stuff.

12-oz. bottle into a pint glass at my house on Dec. 2, 2012 (purchased the 6-pack for $9.99 at Plaza Wine & Spirits in Mira Mesa (San Diego) on Dec. 2, 2012. Golden pale with about a finger of white head with a pretty weak retention all-around.

Very good smell right from the get-go. Got sharp bitter hops right away, giving way to floral hops. Original hops seemed to be citrus with grapefruit, orange and pine coming in.

Tasted a lot like the smell, but not as potent. Got the bitter hops up front - grapefruit, orange, tangerine and pine.

Light body. Thin texture. Average carbonation. Bitter finish.

A very good beer from a very good brewery. No surprise here.

Beer pours a brilliant pale yellow with constant streams of bubbles and a quickly fading white head.  Aroma is very strong with a danky pine note coming forward.  Taste gives citrus hops with little malt presence.  Beer palate comes in the back of the mouth and fades quickly.  Overall this beer would be a great summertime yard beer.  It’s extremely easy to drink and is very refreshing.  If there was a category for session beers, this one would dominate the category.  As a IPA, it’s very different and has a lot of competition!

Nice grapefruit hop aroma; light bready malt. Grapefruit citrus, mild pepper hop flavor. Really light malt, and moderated bitterness Gave this a 14 overall in the previous review, so it looks like I did indeed like this beer more in the summer.

(12/1/12) Fruity, herbal hop flavor and aroma. Really light malt flavor. Should try again if it’s still around in the summer.

Pours translucent golden amber capped by a small off white head. Nose is bustling with light caramel, grapefruit, and mango. Taste is even more an explosion of tropical fruit. Bitterness is solid and over balances. Medium to light body make this extremely gulpable. I would still have a tough time make this a session as it is too drying to the palate.
Sampled in a six pack. Has a nice hop palate. Smooth drinking and quality malts.

12oz bottled August 22nd 2012.  Served at around 40F.



Pours mostly clear, ever so slightly hazy gold with a two finger white head that recedes to a nice cap and leaves pretty drippy rings of lacing behind.



Aroma is citrus, primarily lemon, floral hops, light bready malt.  Very good strength.  Simple, but effective.



Flavor follows suit with juicy lemon hops, a little grapefruit and orange, hint of pine, bready/cracker malt which is light and unobtrusive, nice bitterness, no alcohol.  Finishes dry and light.



Mouthfeel is light/medium bodied, a little sticky, good carbonation.



IMO they nailed it on this one.  Really nice hop aroma and flavor, good bitterness, but keepin’ the alcohol low, making for a very tasty Session IPA.  Even at 3 months old it’s still got big aroma and flavor.  Nice.

There’s a little grapefruit in all of this. The smell makes it a decent IPA from the get-go. Not much malt, just a crisp, hoppy IPA. Has good lacing, pours golden clear. Leave is minimal without much palate. Medium carbonation. On tap at Blue Monk.

Does it always have to be big?  I don’t know.  Probably not... but when I drink this one I can’t help but feel like there’s something missing.  The aroma is full and floral and on the palate you do get a nice blast of bitterness, but there just isn’t much there behind it.  Okay but I can’t see desiring it strongly.

It’s a glorious night: -11C, no wind, fat, slow snowflakes. Out on my fave stairwell in the river valley with my bike and beer. At this point I’m totally covered in snow so I should get to this. iPhone light shows that this is a light pale gold brew. Smells delish! Grapefruit, orange/peach split, lime and lemon, caramel is there as a good base. Sweet pine too. Smells really good - candy sweet at times and it makes my mouth water. This is the coldest beer I’ve had in ages - mainly cuz it’s been sitting in the glass for half an hour as I’ve just been sitting back enjoy absorbing the beauty and wonder that is the west side Edmonton river valley. The taste is quite good but there is a thinness to this one that make it seem watery. The citrus is light overall in power so I assume that piles on as well to that thought. Pine, peach, rrgf, zip and enough bitterness to appease my tasting lumps. Pretty positive that an animal has broken through the ice on the opposite side of the river. Heading home for my car, a rope and an axe to go for a wander in the dark to see if this is indeed the case.

Thanks to iNBe. Big flavor for a low abv beer. Very pale yellow, the missus thought I was drinking a lager. Big hop aroma and flavor. Slightly unbalanced by the low malt but still works. Serving: Bottle

Bottle.  A pale straw pour with a skim of a beige head.  A very pleasing aroma of Mandarin oranges, lemonade, tropical fruits, peaches, zesty citrus rinds, Sour Patch Kids, some grapefruits, and hints of pine.  Thin to medium-bodied and crisp on the way down.  A semi-sweet cereal graininess upfront taste-wise.  Some biscuity qualities in the middle.  The finish is grassy with plenty of tart peaches and tropical citrus fruits.  Herbal hints here and there.  VERY sessionable.
16oz draft pours an orange/ amber with a nice white head.  Aromas of citrus, grapefruit, pine.  Medium bodied, excellent beer

Bottle. Very aromatic - apricots, floral, mint. Light bodied. Tropical fruit and stone fruit, herbal, grassy hops. Thin but satisfying palate. Bitter finish. Lots of flavor for 4.65%. Not quite an IPA, but a magnificent hoppy flavorful session ale.

Bottled. Pours clear pale orange with little head. Bright aroma of citrus and grassy hops and honey-vanilla-cereal malt. Medium bitter flavor. Light body and thin texture, crisp, bitter-astringent finish. Outside of style for sure.

I was sort of excited for this because I knew it was fresh with a julian date of 234 meaning it was bottled on 8/21. That was nine days ago! Bright yellow, looks more like a lager or a very, very pale ale than an IPA. Good head, sticky lacing up the sides of the glass. Smell is super hoppy, mostly fuzzy peaches. Taste is also quite hoppy yet fleeting and touched by a bit of grainy malt. I don’t want to say this is watery but it is very thin. Great for drinking during the day, getting your hop fix and not getting knocked out.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-31-2012 02:11:53

Pours gold into a shaker. White head with medium retention recedes to skim surface.  Sweet tropical fruit and resin aromas. Dry with sweet caramel, bread and and papaya upfront turning to resin and grapefruit in the lasting finish.
Golden colour. Aroma is very hoppy (green, piney). Has a sharp citric edge making it a good thirst quencher. Shame that it was too gassy served from the tap.

Crisp, very light golden coloured body with a thin, soapy white head and a few bubbles rising up against a pale yellow colour. Aroma of pungent light and grassy hops with some hay, yeast, resin and a bit more citrus notes coming through - but all hops, for sure. Light-bodied; Very mild malts coming through, but a good grassy hop note and a light texture with some herbal, fragrant and perfumey hop flavours. Aftertaste is super light with a bit of yeast, some minor herbs, but mostly very minor, grassy hops coming through with no backbone at all of malt. Overall, pretty disappointed with this after seeing good scores and a very nice smell. Good to see a different take on an IPA, but this hasn’t got a malt backbone at all to stand up to the hops, which fade away after a few seconds - tastes like a bit more hoppy anchor steam. I sampled this twelve ounce, stubby Lagy bottle, purchased from Giant Food in Falls Church (Bailey’s Crossroads), Virginia on 11-October-2012 for US$1.67 sampled at home in Washington on 19-November-2012.
Excellent aroma of fruit hop, grapefruit and wine gums. Frothy white head. Medium carbonation. Thin texture. Bitter finish. Easy drinking summer ale.

Bottle from ABC Liquors in Wesley Chapel.  Pours a clear yellow-gold with a white head.  Nose is a nice bouquet of floral and piney hops with hints of citrus and mild grass.   Flavor is a lighter version of the nose: light malt, some nice citrus burst, and then some grassy and herbal hops.  Lingering herbal notes in the finish.  Light in body and an interesting session IPA.

Poured a clear, weak looking yellow color with a lot of carbonation, medium sized white head. Aroma was LOTS of citrus notes, some biscuit malts. Flavor was nice and quite a bit like the aroma, but not nearly as intense. Low ABV is appreciative.
Bottle. Citrus and spice balanced with mild malty sweetness. Pungent. Very light bitter finish. Looking forward to this next summer on the golf course.

Pours light yellow with little head quickly fading into thin layer and decent lacing.  Aroma is outstanding - every citrus fruit you can imagine.  Taste can’t quite live up to the aroma, and has somewhat bitter hops and good malt balance - but overall pretty thin.  Still, for a low ABV IPA, it’s very nicely done.

pours a clear orange gold.  Fluffy finger of white head.  Aroma is citrusy with some notes of resin, lemon, black pepper, skunk, orange.  Medium bodied, with notes of biscuit, and a grainy finish.  Citrus is less pronounced than on the nose but still present.  Overall a nice low-alcohol but full flavored brew that would be nice for lunch on a summer day.

Tap at Beermongers, Portland - 06/11/12. 
Lightly hazed light golden with a thin white head that soon clears to the edge.
Piney nose with bitter grapefruit.
Taste follows nose, citrus, orange pith.
Medium bodied with soft carbonation leading to a bitter finsih.
Decent.
Tap. Dark straw with white dissipating head snag light lacing. Smells piney and cat pissy. Wish the flavor followed. A Tad grainy and hard mouthfeel.

Serviceable IPA on tap at The Cannery Row. Some European hop, citrus fruity, citra like aroma.  Spicy which lends  taste at this surprisingly low abv.  Little sweetness, this is bitter heavy.  Medium bodied.  Cloudy yellow with some retained head.  Not so drinkable, even after it warmed, but served too cold.

Damn, Lagunitas hits it again with this brew! Served with a nice sized foamy, cream-colored head that slowly settles to a light cover and lots of lace. Color is a clear, pale gold with plenty of bubble trails. Aroma is a very pleasing and aromatic blend of hop, malt, caramel, fruit, citrus, with a bit of pine. Flavor’s like nose, sweet/bitter/carbonic tang all perfectly balanced. Body is perhaps a trifle thin, carbonation is great. Finish is like flavor, average length, and superbly drinkable.

A rare lower alcohol IPA in bottle at Stoneyard.  Really tasty offering from start to finish.  Not as overpowering as some.  Pine + tropical notes in the nose.  Tropical feel to the palate along with some malty notes.  Really nice.

Clear pale golden color, foamy white head. Citrus filled hop aroma, with some tropical fruits and cereal notes. Big hop flavor for a beer of its size. Fruity, apricot flavors with a light grassy bitterness. Nice session beer.

Pour is a golden with almost no head.  Aroma is mildly hoppy and not much else.  Deffinatly lets you know you are drinking an IPA.  Flavor is an even better dose of piney hops.  Not much in the way of malt and it’s kinda thin but I guess that’s what keeps the alcohol down.  It’s got enough hop bite and you could deffinatly drink this all day.

On tap at Carpool in Herndon, VA.

Clear, sparkling, yellow with a slight chartreuse tinge with medium-sized white head and excellent lacing. 

Aroma of mango, tangerine citrus, peach and pineapple,  Lovely. 
 
Taste of pineapple, citrus, grapefruit rind and caramel. 

Light body and medium carbonation.

Amazingly powerful and complex aroma that is not matched in the taste.  Rather thin body, but overall an fine job for a low ABV IPA.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cask. Pours hazy gold with thick, frothy white head; decent retention and some lacing. Aroma is grassy and floral hops with biscuit malt, lemon, pine, and light herbs. Flavor is balanced sweet malts and hops (light bitterness) with herbs and citrus esters; dry finish. Medium body and low carbonation.

Pours clear almost yellow colour with little lace and quick head. Hoppy aroma, with a hint of pine cones and that classic lagunita’s fruit loop juicy aroma. light beer, with a fast taste profile, finishes bitter. it is okay but I don’t know if it is worth the price we pay for it here in canad eh!

Sampled on 11/6/2012. This IPA pours a medium yellow color from a 12oz bottle. Medium to large sized white foamy head with decent retention and nice lacing. The aroma is citrusy, tropical, fruity and sweet, and yes hoppy. A medium to lighter bodied India Pale Ale. The malts are fruity and sweet, a touch tropical. The hops are citrusy, piney and grapefruity. Decent carbonation. A nice drinkable IPA, hoppy and slightly bitter with a nice malt backbone. An excellent session IPA. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
Crystal clear light golden yellow. Aroma is awesome, very floral and citrusy, lots of pineapple, crisp malt body. One of the best I’ve had in a long time.

12 ounce bottle at the Bayou. Pours a clear golden color with a medium white head. A great nose of citrus, especially oranges. The flavor is a bit thin and light but very tasty, light bitterness, oranges. Good.

Bottle. Pours a light golden color with very little head. Nose if very floral and hoppy, but inviting. Taste is somewhat hoppy, but balanced well so as not to be all that bitter. VERY light and easy on the palate. Good brew.

Lightly hazy golden color with a small, white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of pine, floral hops, toast, citrus, and tropical fruits. Taste of citrus, pine, various lighter fruits, and a hoppy finish. Top notch.

Bottle pour to shaker.  Very pale gold with quickly dissipating thin head.  It has the citrusy nose of an IPA, but not very aromatic.  That covers the taste, too.  It has hoppiness, bitterness and citrus that reminds me of IPAs I really like, but it is watery.  That is not to say I don’t like it; it is drinkable and much better choice than Bud LIght, etc.

12oz bottle at The Bayou 

Appearance: Clear straw golden with a small white head and some lacing 

Aroma: Citrus and fruity 

Taste: Tropical fruit and lemon 

Very nice and clean, this could be a regular in the fridge if I can get my hands on more.
From a 12 oz bottle at a tasting. Pours clear pale yellow with a white head. Lemon zest in the nose. Floral hops. Mild bitter and refreshing finish.

Bottled sample. Pale gold in colour with strong carbonation. Aromas are of lemon, white grapefruit, cut grass, and a touch of pine sap. Flavors are fairly basic with notes of lemon, light malt, and a hint of white pepper. Very light bodied with moderate bitterness. Probably unfair to compare it to regular strength IPAs, Tasty enough for what it is.
Nice and mild, non-offensive. Low alcohol content. Perfect for coming home, but not yet winding down.

Bottle, 
this ale had a clear yellow gold pour and made a two finger white head that receded to a thin cover and sticky ring that left some rings and spots of lacing on the sides of the glass, 

this little IPA had aromas of grass and floral hops, powdered sugar, some toasted malt and faint caramel, 

it had flavors of grass, bitter hops, some toasted malt, faint caramel and fruit with very little sweetness, 
the finish had hop bitterness with little to no malt and left the palate pretty dry, 

the mouth feel was light on the palate, there was some creaminess and average to lively carbonation, 

lots of hops with little malt on the nose, same for the flavor, a light malt, hoppy easy drinking beer.
Excellent citrus hop aroma! Boring super clear amber color. Thin body and head. Top notch hops but little malt!

12oz bottle pours a clear golden with a small white head. Aroma of spicy resinous hops which kind of remind me of sweet grape juice. Taste is pretty simple a hit of resinous pine hops turning sweet and falling off at the finish. Not amazing but enjoyable and very sessionable.
Hazy gold,large white head.Spicy piney nose.Watery piney citrus hop for and mid, long bitter hop finish.Great lace

Pours straw gold. Aroma is like an ipa - citra and simcoe hops i think, taste is dry, no bitterness and not much of a malty body at all (obviously).  I like more malt and body to a beer so not my thing. But, this beer is a great concept and should do a lot to get bud light drinkers to try craft beer

Bottle. Pours with a two-finger white head with on top of a golden-yellow body. Some light lacing left behind. The nose is grapefruit along with mixed citrus and a savory pine note. Taste is mildly biter and lightly sweet. Dry with citrus flavors and mild malt foundation. Finishes clean with mild bitterness. Body is light to medium. Pretty good stuff, better than the other low ABV APA/IPAs I’ve tried.

Draft at ebp. Pours a crystal clear bright medium gold with a loose white creamy head. Big fresh piney grapefruit nose with herbal undertones. Light sparkling body with pleasant wooly mouthfeel, great carb. Toasty mid palate with great dancing pine and grapefruit highlights and long crisp resiny finish.

Bottle. Clear yellow color. Light hoppy east drinking APA.good day drinking beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This poured a lighter pale yellow color with a white head.  Aroma was of freshly picked fruity and grassy hops, and not much else.  Flavor was much the same, extremely light, but loaded with hop flavor and almost zero bitterness.  I can’t possibly think of a better session beer.

On tap at Blind Tiger NYC, poured into a pint glass.
Clear yellow color, no head.
Fruity nose, citric and tropical, with some hay.
Bready flavor, light fruit, a touch of acid and medium bitterness.
Light body, dry and highly drinkable. Cool.

Multiple bottles courteys of Vin and Pat. Pours a clear yellow golden body with fizzy white lacing. Aroma is super fresh pine, bitter crisp hop. Mouthfeel is thin bodied and crisp; very sessionable with notes of grassy hop, light dank herbal character and light bitter pine.

On tap at the Ginger Man.  Pours a hazed straw gold with a medium sized white head.  Big bright citrus, candied citrus with a light sweetness.  A touch thinner than the nose suggests, but that’s rather nice, making this super drinkable.  Refreshing, crisp, long slow pithy bitterness.  Super balanced, lovely.  Wonderful to see such a nice hoppy session beer from Lagunitas.

Bottle. 12 oz. Had a couple of these over the past two days with Janine, Vinny, and James. Pours cearish yellow-golden with a thin, bubble white head which dissipates quickly. Leaves a little white ring of lace around the surface and edge of the glass. Aroma is a knockout: pure oniony garlic with some earthy, grassy, subttly citric notes. Tastes a bit grassy and has notes of pilsner malts. Very refreshing, clean and easy-going beer. At 4.5%, it’s a perfect session beer. This is great.

Pours crystal clear golden yellow, thin white head, very light spotty lacing. Nice fruity hop aroma, a little citrus too. Tropical fruit hops in the flavor with nicely balanced malt in the body. Great light body, medium high carbonation, clean feel with lingering hop resin in the finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from beer fridge / sherm1016.  Pours clear orange color and thin white head.  Bright with hops right upfront....but not much more behind it.  Great for a "it’s not 5 o’clock yet" beer but lacks a certain something...but still really really refreshing.

UPDATED 3/23/13...had another last night...bet I had a stale one before...more substance and brighter flavor...excellent by any IPA standard

12oz bottle from Sonoma Cellers Delavan. Pours a crystal clear, bright yellow with a whitehead and some lacing.  Aroma is Frash, green, hoppy, grassy.  Medium on the palate with average carbonation. Flavor is bitter, hoppy, pine, a bit watery, maybe a little bready sweetness, but not much, with a light, bitter finish.  Not bad, but the other "Day" IPA is better.

Pours a very clear, very pale yellow color with a nice foamy head that lingers a long time.  Big lemon and grapefruit aroma.  Taste is a fresh citrus hop taste.  Solid bitterness in the finish.  A little toasted malt is detectable.  While this IPA is nothing special, its still a very drinkable session IPA.
Bottle. Golden-straw beer with a whitish head. Grapefruit and pine aroma. Grapefruit and light malt flavor. Medium bodied. Good bitterness. Grapefruit and light pine lingers with light malt.

Surprisingly bitter. Soapy hops and big toasty malt taste fight for attention. Feels a bit watery as might be expected. The lower strength makes it nicely dry from all the hops, but there is a metallic aftertaste unlike Lagunita’s other IPAs.

12oz bottle in a shaker.  Pours golden with an off-white head.  Aroma of floral and citrusy hops with some pale malts.  Flavor the same.  Average to almost light texture.  A good beer for what it’s supposed to be.

pours a clear pale yellow-straw with a small white head, above average carbonation, and good lacing.

smell is of hops, citrus, a touch of pine, and some sweetness in the back.

taste is crisp, hoppy, some pine, light grapefruit, grass, and a little malt in the end.
This one is OK.  I hoped for more from such a great brewery but this was a bit too malty and out of balance for such a light beer.  Still easy drinking and good just not my thing,.

12 oz bottle.  Pours clear straw yellow with a big frothy white head that retains well and laces the glass some.



The aroma is dank, piney, resiny hops and some tropical fruits.



The flavor is a bit mild - some tropical fruits and dank resiny hops.  The mouthfeel is medium bodied with low carbonation and is a bit watery and washed out.



Overall, I like the lower ABV hoppy beers.  This has good bitterness and hop profile, it just seems a bit watery and washed out.  I recall liking Founder’s All Day IPA better.

12 oz bottle.  Clear pale yellow with a webby white head.  Nose is orange, grapefruit, pine and toffee; a big citrus blast.  Bready medium light with a brisk tingle.  Taste is lemon, pink grapefruit and pine.  Clean and easy drinking.  I can see this one in my summer rotation.

Slightly cloudy straw color with a frothy head. Notes of sweet tropical fruit, pine/resin, and a delicate malt base. Well balanced and very easy drinking...difficult to do considering the low ABV and big flavor. Easily a new go-to beer.

Bottle at craft ale house. Pours clear yellow with a small white head. There is tons of carbonation in the glass. The aroma is full of pine and some additional hippy notes. The taste is medium bitter with a nice bitter finish. This is fairly one dimensional but I prefer unbalanced India pale ales.

Aroma is citrus, orange, and fruity, with a slight hint of malt. The appearance is pale yellow, with the sightest hints of gold. Light bodied taste as IPAs go (I know, it’s not a true IPA with the full amount of hops), taste confirms the aroma. Nice malt finish.

355ml bottle.
Pours a medium straw, with a white head.
Hoppy, resiny aroma, spruce, grapefruit peel, grass, lemon, apricot, almost a light smokiness.
Dry, medium body, high bitterness, balanced CO2.
Hoppy, spicy taste, resin, spruce, grapefruit peel, grass, malt.
Lots of taste for a low ABV, a bit over-bitter for the slim body, though. (2012-10-19)

Man! What a great sessionable beer! Not sure how Lagunitas packed that much hop flavor in a beer so light, but they did. Aroma was delicious. Grassy hops, hay and even notes of pollen. Pour was a nice light gold with plenty of rising bubbles and and a one finger white head. Taste was bursting with hop flavor. The grassy and hay flavor was joined by mango and and melon flavors. Very light sticky and prickly malt backbone. Nice carbonation round this beer out. Great beer that I will seek out again.

Bottle. Pale golden body with a thick lasting white head. Aroma and flavour are guided by lovely bold tropical fruit hop character, lots of guava and passionfruit. Underlying malts are light, but the hops here are so aromatically pleasant that it doesn’t matter. This IPA may be light on ABV, but it doesn’t scrimp on flavour. Another great brew from Lagunitas.
Golden body with a small white head. The aroma is Amarillo-esque with some biscuit and toasted notes. The flavor is similar, maltier than it looks. Finishes crisp with light bitterness. Pretty good.

Really liked this beer. It has a real light taste with a just a hint of hops. Laguniitas has an outstanding beer line and I would recommend their beers to everyone.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Spirits Lacey. pours out a clear golden color with a small white head. Aroma is of citrusy hops, light tropical fruits and a little bit of crisp, toasty malt notes in there. Taste is lightly bready/toasted grain malt notes, light fruit, acidic hop notes, citrus and light grassy notes in there as well. Definitely a nice session.
Bottle from 6 pk.  Color is light yellow. White head. Aroma is really hoppy and grass. Taste is slightly hops at start with a slight bitter finish. Good IPA for 4.7%

A great session IPA! Big citrusy nose and flavor with a nice bready malt character to balance it out! Very tasty!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle into a pint glass.

Pours a clear pale straw yellow with a one finger white head fading to a thin layer of bubbles. Ok lacing.

Aroma is full of citrus hops. Lots of passion fruit and grapefruit. A tiny bit of pale malt is evident but hops really dominate.

This carries over into the flavor. Moderate to high bitterness begins immediately and tropical fruit flows across the tongue. A very tiny bit of pale malt and toast is in the background but hops really dominate. Mouthfeel is on the watery side as can be expected from a beer of this strength (or lack thereof).

Overall, this is a very tasty session beer that packs great flavor in a small package. Mouthfeel does suffer but it is a small price to pay for having a tasty light beer. Other brewers really need to explore this type of beer.

Golden beer with a white head. Lively carbonation gives this beer a very effervescent look. Aromas are of powerful hops, smells of fresh cut grass. Tastes of fresh cut grass, lots of spruce, pine hops, very forest-like flavors. Decent malt backbone works with the hops in harmony. There is a tiny hint of grapefruit in the finish, but the finish is mostly of bitter hops. Very tasty, and drinkable. I recommend this to anyone looking for an IPA with some bite without the high ABV.

Bottle thanks to John. Pours straw gold - semi-cloudy- with quickly dissipating white head. Nose/taste of grapefruit, pine, light resin, toasted grain and soap. Finishes dry pine and a little soapy. Lighter bodied.

I was excited for this beer.  Pours a straw color with a thin soapy head that fades quickly.  Aroma is piney grapefruit, and light soapiness.  This is kind of like a pilsner-IPA variant.  I don’t care for the soapy bitterness and just the hops used in this beer.

I can’t more simply or more accurately describe this as Lagunitas IPA light.  Nose is very similar; citrus, pine, very strong.  Palate is as well; it’s very bitter up front with pine and resin and a quick fall off to a crisp finish.  There’s less in the palate (duh) and less body, but overall taste is pretty close.  You lose some palate depth to save the alcohol, but this is a very good session beer.

Bottle: &nbsp Pale golden, vibrant, clear, light carbonation, moderate to large frothy white head, nice lacing. &nbsp Soft hoppy nose, minor floral and citrus notes, very minor. &nbsp Similar tongue, a bit spritzy, minor hops with a little bit of sweet floral and citrus notes. &nbsp Feels more like a Pale Ale to me, a good one. &nbsp Light for an IPA... then again, @ 4.65% it is a light IPA. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate. &nbsp Clean finish, very light on the hops by this time. &nbsp Makes me think this is even a lighter Pale Ale. &nbsp Gotta say not a great IPA, but a fairly good and light PNW style Pale Ale. &nbsp I’ll give it that much.
Draught. First our second pull of the keg. beautiful fresh floral and tropical fruit hop profile and taste. Nice grassy malts. Soft lovely MF. such a nice surprise.

Reviewed 10/14. 12 oz. bottle poured into a pint glass.

A: Pours a medium straw color with fantastic clarity. I’d say it looks like a pilsner, but not many pilsners I’ve seen featured the kind of frothy, thick head this one does. The two finger eggshell colored head retains acceptably. 

S: This has the smell I’m accustomed to from Lagunitas IPAs, with a combination of herbal ’green-ness’ and grapefruit peel. Just a faint hint of sweetness abounds, as well.

T: The malts here are very neutral and crackery, and are seemingly only there to provide a canvas for the hops to shine. Speaking of, the hops start out as being slightly piny and herbal, before gradually transitioning to a citrusy finish. This has a combination of lightness and balance, which equals massive drinkability.

M: Clean, dry, and refreshing. There are some accumulating hop oils after a while, but hardly enough to ruin drinkability. It’s not ’watery’ per se, but it goes down like hop-flavored water.

O: I’m not normally this much above the rAvg on one of my reviews, and even less normally willing to give out 20’s, but this has everything I look for in an IPA. It’s light, crisp, juicy, somewhat inexpensive, and even slightly complex. Put simply, I could buy this stuff by the case and never get tired of it.

Pours clear gold with a fluffy white head.  Aroma is pine, citrus, grass and tropical.  Taste is sweet with moderate bitters.  Light bodied with a sticky yet very smooth texture.  Just a great session IPA, it smells fantastic and tastes just as good.

12oz bottle pours clear gold with thin off white head of foam. The aroma is nice and citrusy with a mix of grapefruit and tangelo with little else going on. But with this little beer what more could you want? On a somewhat thin watery palate the taste delivers the same citrus notes noted in the nose. It has a mix of bitter citrus like hops that get meekly filled in by thin streams of citrusy hop flavor. Nice flavorful session brew but good gravy was this expensive, almost $11 for a six? What! So that bothered me and I’d easily plunk down $9.99 instead for some Sugga or Undercover or better yet GnarlyWine. For me the high price takes away from the experience.

Pours light golden with thin and sticky head. Great crisp hoppy aroma. Super good IPA with the low ABV.  Best I have had like it. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Purchased at Evolution Wine & Spirits in Chicago, IL; enjoyed on a Saturday afternoon while doing some song writing.  I didn’t take notes while having this, but I remember this being a nice, crisp and light pale ale with a pronounced hoppy, citrus profile.  Very good, refreshing stuff.

12 oz bottle from Spirits Crossroads. Poured a good looking clear golden body with an average sized frothy bright white head. Aroma is awesome, could smell this all day. Notes of citrus, apricot, mango, sweet hop cones,, tropical fruits and citrus rinds. The palate is solid with a medium body and strong carbonation with small tight bubbles that is pleasant and an average duration on the aftertaste. Favor sadly isn’t as great as the aroma, the tropical fruits start to take over a bit and the citrus takes a back seat to a point, there is also a slight touch bad citrus fruits along with dry grains and a midway flavor of ad butterscotch. Great beer overall and I think the flavor could be rounded out a bit to make this an outstanding beer, especially with the lower ABV.
good easy drinker, a little on the bland side, grassy and soem citrus in there, very simple

Clear golden pour, thin white bubbly frothy head .... sticky lacing .... aroma of grapefruits, mangos, piney and fresh lemony hops ... Taste of fruity citrusy lemony hops, grapefruit and piney, malty toasted and caramel flavors on the backend ... Bitterness is subtle not too intense... Dry malty and bitter finish ... Resiny and a bit rindy. Delicious.

A vigorous pour into my Tripel Karmeliet tulip produces a two finger thick, pale, off-white colored head. The beer is a full gold color that shows a brilliantly clear, bright yellow-gold hue when held up to the light. The hop character just jumps out of the glass; aromas of super tropical fruit, lychee, candied floral peaches, ripe kumquat zest, and candied tangelo sit on top of a more dank, herbal character. These notes contribute aromas of pine needles, peppery rosemary, and a hint of chive / onion character.



Exceedingly light bodied, with a peppery hop and carbonic bite. The bitterness is quite biting here, and it couples with a peppery, woody, herbal note in the finish. The hop character is quite muted, as compared to the nose, this is expected as there is almost no malt sweetness here to support the bright fruity / floral hops. A touch of hop character does come through though, with notes of Meyer Lemon zest, grapefruit zest, and watered down citrus juice. Lots of green pine needle notes, and a woody peppery character.



The aroma is really fantastic on this beer; the body and flavor doesn’t live up to that promise, though I didn’t really expect it to, as this was supposed to be an exceedingly hoppy, low alcohol IPA. Pretty good for what it is, but definitely drink this on the warm side as it gets a bit more balance then.

Pours a light gold with a thick white head. Aroma of dank resinous hops. Citrus and pine. Taste starts as the nose does but huge melon flavor in the middle and finish. Light and ridiculously easy to drink. I might have a new favorite ipa.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Man this is really good IPA... Looks wise.... it looks like a light lager. You can see straight through. Decent little head, that quickly faded. Smells great. Piney, fruity, mango, pineapple, lots of tropical fuits. Taste even better.... lots of tropical fruits, mango, pineapples with a nice light grass taste. Really light fluffy body, clean and crisp. Way to easy to drink. Overall: Reminds me of zombie dust. Great brew! Wish I had this on draft or fresh bottles in the summer. Bottle picked up at SL

12 oz. bottle, pours a clear pale golden yellow with a medium white head. Nose is full piney and floral hops, a bit of soap, a bit of herbal, pot-like hops as well, and some sweet cereal / graham crackery malt to back. Flavour is fairly sweet (for a low ABV IPA) and quite dry and bitter at the same time, with floral and grassy hops, sweet cereal malts, finishing dry, with crackery mats. Good hoppy, light, refreshing session IPA.

Bottle at pour house, couldn’t be any fresher. Pours a somewhat clearish golden color medium white head that didn’t last. Aromas of tangy, cheesy hops, tons of garlic, fuel and resin. Taste is just as incredible, with citrus fuel, pine resin, onions, garlic, dank herbs. Medium bodied, refreeshing. Finishes with a sessionable pale flavor. I could drink this till I died. Lagunitas always dominates the hop game. Awesome.

Bottle from Total wine ABC Vero Beach. Pours golden with an inch of white foam. Big grass notes on the nose. Big. Lots of grass on the tongue as well as the malt that was there. Clean finisher. Another winner from Lagunitas.
Snallygaster, draft.  Medium white head, clear light amber body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, orange, some grapefruit.  Taste is moderately sweet, orange/grapefruit.  Light-medium body, light acidity.

A clear, yellow-orange pour with a frothy, white head.  The aroma has some nice grapefruit and mild pine.  It has a light, somewhat oily body with average carbonation.  The taste is pretty balanced with some slight bitterness in the finish.

Bottle. Pours well, piss yellow, with a slight white head. Very nice, big, citrus aroma. Taste is juicy but dry without too much bitterness. Finishes like a pilsner. Can say that this is exactly what it advertises.

Pours a clear pale yellow with a medium white head.  Aroma has some skunky and grassy notes with a bit of grapefruit.  Flavor has stonefruits...mango, peach...and grapefruit...tastes like the small beer from holiday sucks.  Mouthfeel is light/medium and lively with a stonefruity dry finish.

pour is pale yellow with a decently thick white head and lots of lace left. Nose is faint pale malt and some sticky caramel with an assertive pine hop and a light green herbal note. Taste is more pale malt and grain with a very solid hop backbone, lightly herbal and sweet hops with a gentle bitterness, clean carbonated crisp finish, and semi dry. Extremely sessionable and tasty.

Draft at Snallygaster, DC on October 13th, 2012. Another I finally got to try. A nice amount of hop flavor and nose, but good balance and would be enjoyable. Now I need to find it cheaper than the $15!! a six pack the store near me was offering it at.
Bottle. Golden hazy pour with white head. Citrus and spice floral hop aromas. Lighter hop flavor, has citrus and floral tones. Light in body.
Pours clear golden amber with a creamy head on top. Aroma bring sweet citrus hops. The flavor brings juicy sweet citrus hops so full for a sessionable IPA. Highly enjoyed on tap in Philly.

This is the most flavorful beer I've ever had that's less than 5% alcohol. The hops really come through here- easily drinkable but enjoyable. Wish I had discovered this during the summer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The grapefruit flavors drip out of this one.  All the hops of a DIPA but in a...errr.... 1/2IPA?  A bit of necessary loss of points on palate and overall due to the lack of alcohol, but hard to bash someone for what they are going for.  A great use of hops gets them to this score.  Their marketing is true, yet...do we need a craft beer for the MGD65 market?  Hell, I dunno, tasty ass hops!

Draft at Capone’s.  Pours hazy dull gold with white head that laces well.  Nose is big floral hops, Saazy, with some spicy and fruity notes.  Tasted hoppy, floral, with finishing spicy and Saazy hops and peppery crispness.

My new fav daily drinker.  Fantastic aroma and great taste.  Light and refreshing without being bland.  Malt backbone is mostly lost in glorious dank aroma and citrus flavor.  Sure hope they keep this on for a year rounder.

ultra fresh bottle.    aroma of clean juicy pineapple and grapefruit.   gumballhead-esque hop profile.    taste is bright crisp grapefruit, lemongrass.    touch of toast.   body is a bit watery, but im fine with dat.   sessionable.  tasty.   seems pretty good to me with these here tacos.
Smells like pine, marijuana, and some sweet. Pours a somewhat pretty bright yellow. Flavours are pine needles...thin mouthfeel.
Draft at Capone’s. Pours a pale yellow with soome head.Nose is nice  with notes of lemon and citrus peal. first sipis similar with a nice clean finish.  i love this beer.

On tap at the Jackson Avenue Pub in Naperville, IL. Pours a crystal clear, straw-gold colored body with a finger-width, frothy, white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a moderate lacing. Aroma is very fruity with a nice juicy citrus hop element plus a grainy pale malting. Grassy with some floral tropical fruits, a bit of a lemon-zest, a light earth, and a touch of toast. Flavor isn’t as vibrant and fruity, but still really nice. Citrusy florals with some grass and a light earthiness, a few tropical fruits, and a nice bitterness throughout. Grainy pale malt backing with a touch of toast before this finishes crisp, clean, moderately bitter, and dry before leaving a lengthy aftertaste. Light body and a crisp, moderate carbonation. Overall, a really solid, flavorful IPA. Lots of fruity hops and a firm bitterness, but really crisp, light, and refreshing thanks to the lower ABV%. Good one.

9 Oct 2012, bottle. pale yellow, clear, occasional bubbles. fantastic grapefruit aroma; slightly sweet, big citrus, doesn’t smell too aggressive. thin body and moderately fizzy. taste is pine and mild grapefruit rind. very crisp, no lingering bitterness. i’m having a hard time thinking of this as an ipa. it is very crisp and bitter but lacks alcohol and body. still, very good.
On tap at Capone’s. Poured an amber color with an off white head. Floral hops, citrus, and toasted grassiness.

12oz. bottle.  Big citrus aroma, fairly well leaps out of the glass, with plenty of lemon and grapefruit, some grassy, herbal notes and just a hint of honeyish sweetness.  Clear pale golden in color with a lasting, fine head fed by several streams of bubbles.  Flavor profile is fairly simple, with leafy, grassy, almost minty hop tones blended with citrus and very faint touches of toasty, lightly sweet malts, finishing with a kick of hop bitterness.  Dry, light and effervescent on the palate, with a light-medium body.  This is exactly what it claims to be, just a light, low-gravity, drinkable IPA.  Great for warm weather.
Very hoppy citrus aromas. Lemon, tangerine, and Orange peel flavors. Finishes dry with a little bitterness.  Overall a very good beer.

Pours clear yellow / light gold with a soapy white head.  The aroma has grapefruit, pineapple, funk and pale malt.  Its quite dry and very hoppy for a beer less than 5% abv.  Medium / light crisp body with a decent amount of fairly soft carbonation for the style.  The flavor begins with more balance than the aroma.  There is pale cracker-like malt and hops that highlight pine and grapefruit.  The finish shows some tropical fruit and is very dry with the malt and the grapefruit pith notes of the hops.  Very nicely done.
Clear pour from 12 oz bottle.  PRetty serious floral aroma.  Light color, minor malts and not as hoppy as scented.  A good beer for light session.

Stanley’s Beer Fest 10/6, TAP. Smells good... but faint smell of urine. Upon drinking, more urine aroma. I also get resin, grain, pine hops, and some citrus. Aroma and taste is complex but the body is watery. Not impressed.

Goes to show that you don’t need a big ABV for a really tasty beer. This has a pale yellow pour but don’t be fooled. Take a whiff of the hop goodness to come. The flavor is nicely balanced. Goes down so easy, very dry and refreshing.

Tap: clear light-yellow with small white head. Aroma is grassy and citrus, pine, and cat pee hoppy. Flavor is grass, straw, pine, orange, grapefruit, and a light honey sweetness. Palate has a nice sweetness balancing the hoppy bitter and a somewhat thin body. Nice smooth, flavorful easy drinking beer.

Bottle at home, from my Minneapolis Town Hall glass. Pours deep honey-gold, with a thick, persistent white head, that laces extremely well. Nose is big fresh pine, pineapple, grapefruit, lots to like in the nose here. Flavours of spicy juniper, grapefruit, really makes the mouth tingle. Malt background is perhaps a shade lighter than "appropriate", but I really like how the hops shine through as a result. A thoroughly excellent beer, one that I see buying myself many times in the future.
Light bodied? Check/ Low ABV? Check. Hop forward? Check. Affordable? Check. I think I have a new one for my session beer rotation...

Clear gold body, bright white head, and very nice lace. Citrusy aroma, mostly grapefruit and orange, with hints of pepper, doughy bread and spices. Crisp hops bitterness accompanied by toasted malts, nuts, leafy greens, and black pepper. Medium body, lively carbonation, and a crisp dry finish.

Pours a clear golden yellow color with a one finger white head that quickly settles into a lasting ring. Spotty lacing left behind. 

Floral hop aroma with a balance of resinous pine, tropical fruit and pale malt. Spicy hop character with hints of grass, pineapple and lemon peel followed by bread, biscuit and grainy cracker. 

Medium bodied but fuller than expected with a complex hop profile countered by a pale malt backbone. Some dry, earthy bitterness up front followed by tropical/citrus sweetness. There’s a spicy hop bite with some sticky pine needle flavor countered by hints of pineapple and lemon juice before finishing with biscuity malt. Crisp, refreshing, extremely drinkable and packed with delicious hop flavors. I could drink this all night.
One of the better session ipas ive had. Had the typical lagunitas tropical hop ipa aroma and flavors. As you can imagine just a more watery ipa. Enjoyable

Aroma is a very earthy/grassy hop. Very pleasant. Looks like a golden pale ale, complete with small white head, but tastes earthy and hoppy, and not much else. Palate is thick from carbonation, but without that would be watery and refreshing instead of thick and heavy.

Pale straw colour with a fast-dissipating white head. The aroma is incredible. Lemon, grapefruit, kiwi, and a touch of papaya and mango. Very light malt component with a bit of crackery flavour and some light bitterness. This stuff is awesome. Incredibly hoppy and aromatic yet completely quaffable.

Pours a clear golden yellow with a big white head.  I could smell the hops while I was filling my glass.  Huge resinous hop aromas of grapefruit, spicy black pepper, and fruity esters (mango?).  Light, crisp body that is super clean, super balanced, and super smooth.  Little malt and just a dab of fruity grapefruit in the taste.  The epitome of a summer quencher.  I could drink a ton of these and will starting tonight.

This was a draft pour from THE LOCAL beer bar in Eureka, CA.  It came in the pint glass a clear bright light yellow with a small white head.  Kind of looked like a  cheap macro lager. But when raised the glass up to your nose you know otherwise. This greets you with a big hop laden aroma of citrus.  Body is far bolder than it looks, with a smooth slick resinous mouthfeel. The flavor is full of flavor with citrus and pine on a rich caramel malt base and tasted very fresh. The finish is dry and perfectly bitter, and the whole beer is in excellent balance. Very easy drinking and refreshing and shows that a really good beer does not have to be high in alcohol to be good. Perfect session beer for the hop head.

Bottle to a Duvel tulip. Pours a clear yellow gold, almost pilsner like, with a thin, off white head that quickly disappears. Aroma is fruity hops and lawn. There is orange, peach, and a little grapefruit, along with some bready caramel. Taste is kind of muted. Some mild orange and grapefruit flavors are there, as well as bread and a little caramel. Mouthfeel is thin and very watery. Overall it’s good but not that great. For the style, Founder’s all day IPA is a much better session beer. I wish I didn’t pay 12 bucks for a 6 pack of this.

bottle from Bottle Revolution. I’m really digging this one. Lagunitas has successfully pulled off the super hoppy light-bodied pale ale. Everything here is crystal clear on my palate. The light malts give this a smooth palate and just a mild sweetness to act as a canvas for the hops. Like most Lagunitas offerings, this one is filthy dank. The bitterness is very herby and filthy nasty. The finish gives way to hints at melon. I really hope this one shows up around here, though it is fading into cooler autumn weather and I’ll probably crave more full-bodied beers.

12 oz bottle. pours a pale yellow with a nice white head. big floral / citrus hop nose. med body with big citrus notes, a light lemon tartness and some bread notes. big bitter finish. this one delivers!

This begins with a floral hop aroma, and pours a clear light amber, with a thin white head.  Crisp floral hop presence, very little malt backbone there, and a very light mouthfeel.  It’s a very drinkable beer, and one that is quite enjoyable, even if there isn’t much there.

Very much water like on the pour. Light yellow in color, clear with a large white foam head. Smells, sweet, citrus-y and definitely some grapefruit on the nose. Body is light and watery with a lot of carbonation. Coming off of summer, I was excited for a light IPA as Kolsh’s and lagers sometimes have very little flavor. While not bland like those styles, this isn’t a terribly exciting beer. The first thing you taste is water, their are light citris hops and a nice toasted malt. Finishes with the light hops and is quite sessionable. If i could get this in a twelve pack of cans for cheap sure but not in a 6p at 12p price...

Pale golden color out of the bottle with a thin off white head.  Fresh pine and apricot nose.  Big pinching grapefruit juice, pine and orange peel flavors.  A little thin for the style but a very flavorful and drinkable beer.

Light amber with an orange tint. Floral nose with some lemony hints. Medium bodied, citrus heavy IPA. This shows a good mix of herbal minty flavors with some soft hop bite. Medium length finish. Refreshing.

12oz bottle: pours a clear bright golden with a thin-lacing wispy white head. Has a fresh resinous hoppy nose with some dank pine and a touch of lightly toasted malts. Starts with average fullness and mild sweetness with some faint huskiness and lots of fresh juicy hop flavor and good bitter balance. Easy drinking and refreshing without being flavorless.
Amber in color, clear with a thin head.  Big hops aroma and flavor.  This was a suoper tasty light ale.  Great Session brew.

Pint on tap. Hazy golden with a quarter inch of cream. Pleasant resin and caramel toast aromas. Flavor is more of the same with big resin and light grapefruit finish. Light-medium body is watery, drinkably hop-tingly and dry, and has medium carbonation.
Bottle shared by Marcus. Pours gold with a foamy off-white head. Aroma is laid-back citrus. Med minus body. Citrus hop. Very light malt. Good beach or lawnmower or session ale.
Bottle from Davis Beer Shoppe. Pours golden with a rich off-white head and a very hoppy citrus aroma. There is a hearty pale malt flavor with balanced bitterness. A nice session beer.

12oz bottle. From the bottle so no pour this time. Aromas of caramel, pine, citrus rind, and a slight floral note. Flavor is full of piney/citrusy hops. The body is light and finishes smooth. This reminds me of a Sumpin’ Light. Thanks much Lag!!

New Beer Distributors, NY 355ml ($2.25): Pours a copper with a nice white head. Aroma is citus, resin, and a bit of pine. Malt backbone is light, but substantial enough not to be watery. Hoppiness is moderate and well-varied. The beer is nice and sessioable and could probably be drank at any time (I drank it at 3 in the morning, so I violated the spirit of the beer).

Poured bright gold.  Very strong oily grapefruits and pine hop nose.  Then things start to unravel,  way to thin, unbalanced hop to malt.  No support from the malts.  Almost undrinkable.  This didn’t work for me.

(bottle) Clear, bubbling straw body, small white head. Very fruity nose. Citrus (orange, grapefruit) and some pine hops, strawberry, grape, toasted grain. Light body, carbonated. Dry hop flavor, medium bitterns, grain, bread, undertones of fruit. Very dry.

Can (Dec 21, 2018 canning).

Head is initially average sized, frothy, white, mostly diminishing.
Body is light to medium yellow.

Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), moderately hoppy (lemon oil, grapefruit, herbs), with a light note of onion.

Flavor is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter.

Light body, watery texture, lively/fizzy carbonation.

A slight improvement from when I first had it over 6 years ago, but it's very thin and watery and overly attenuated (at least to be enjoyable). It's drinkable, I'll concede, and I get that they're sorta aiming this at people counting calories, but still...at this point you might as well just drink hop water or sparkling water and eliminate calories and booze altogether.

The aroma is incredibly hoppy with grapefruit and floral type hops and light sweet malt. The appearance is straw gold with a medium head. The taste is like the aroma and so easy to drink it’s almost crazy. The palate is thin but OK. Overall a great beer.
This beer has  a great aroma with fresh hops are a nice bouquet. the beer  itself is actually very thin but very drinkable. The way too many flaws but its still very enjoyable.

12oz bottle. Pours golden with white head that leaves a little ring of lace. Lots of fresh citrus and spruce on the nose and not much else. Really sprucey. The same on the palate. Lots of spruce and not much else. Good but simplistic.

12 oz bottle poured into my PBR Goblet, from Roth’s Sunnyslope market S.Salem.
$6.99 a six pack
Pours a clear gold/straw colour with a lovelly thick and bubbly white head.
Gorgeous spicy/resiney hop notes in the aroma a little hay like malt in the backing.
Taste all hop but yu can tell the caramel malt is in the back,but its all kind of wishy washy i am afraid compared to the aroma.
Ok palate..thin and drinkable
Not bad but was expecting more

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy gold color with a short lived diminishing white head. Aroma is of grassy citrus pine. Dry biscuity pale malts blend with tangy lemon citrus hops to provide a really nice balance. Crisp, dry, bitter finish. A very nice session ale from Lagunitas!

Pours a slightly hazy yellow with a short white head. I has a wonderful hop aroma of pine, grapefruit, and grass. The flavor is light, with a slight hop flavor up front and a maltier middle and balanced aftertaste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A surprising IPA. Very light body, crisp yellow color. Highly hopped, big nose, very piney. The taste is nicely balanced big malt and big hops. The lower alcohol content lets you enjoy a few without putting you under the table!

12oz bottle.  Orange yellow with some slight chill haze, otherwise looks pretty filtered out.  Thin, oily white head.  Really great session beer.  Tropical melon and dry straw hops.  Clean golden malt backbone.  The melon tones are really quite pronounced.  Easy going, hoppy, but not biting.  Excellent.

Light gold with a slight haze - compact, mostly diminishing head - the nose is really quite lovely - dry, crackery malt, a kind of flinty mineral character, and a nice mix of hop characteristics (citrus, grassy, spiciness) - the flavor has a nice crisp driness to it, but the malt is a little husky and rough (not enough to make me dislike it, but meh) - the flavor is a bit too lemony and the hops lack the complex punch the aroma promises - a bit of a let down, but I like it okay.

Bottled.  Poured clear, bright golden with a short-lived white head.  The aroma picked up lemon zest and grassy hoppage over soft pale and bready notes.. light and fresh.  The flavor found tangy lemon and citrus throughout, with a light, pale base.. crisp and clean, but a little too lemony.  Lighter-bodied and tangy on the palate.. refreshing and easy-drinking.

12oz bottle poured into snifter. Light golden color with a thin fluffy head. Nice hoppy floral aroma with just a tad of citrus. Flavor/mouth feel is pretty light, which sort of surprised me. Super easy to drink and very session-able.

12oz bottle- straight outta the bottle!  I wanted to test this brew’s ability to match it’s unofficial purpose of an all day, low alcohol pale ale that doesn’t kill your palate over time and/or get you too loose too fast as a sixer of a typical pale would.  Did some day drinking and treated it as a high quality hop-based craft beer to utilize as a sixer of Budweiser except of the impressive craft variety.  It’s now my official football Sunday beer.  Nice hop character on the nose from the Mosaics, light bodied and mellow hops on the finish but great flavor.  Great idea!  Love that I can come to expect outside the box brews like this from Tony & Co!

Bottled September 11, 2012.



A: This is an excellent looking pale ale that is textbook for the style. Day Time has a pale golden body with sparse carbonation bubbles lazily floating to the thick white head. The head could use better retention, but freshly poured this looks beautiful.



S: Oh what a wonderful tropical hop aroma with mangoes, pineapple, and nectarines and a lightly toasted malt background. This is the best smelling pale ale I’ve had.



T: The hop bitterness asserts itself from the start reminding me a bit of lemons and provides a moderate bitterness, some tropical flavors hang in the background and a very lightly toasted dryness comes through a bit towards the end. 



M: Light with light carbonation.



O: This is an excellent session pale ale and Lagunitas would be silly to not make this year round. Well done.

12 ounce can into pint glass, canned on 12/14/2018. Pours slightly hazy pale golden yellow color with a 1 finger fairly foamy and fluffy head with great retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice spotty foamy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big tangerine, red grapefruit, lemon, peach, pineapple, passion fruit, mango, melon, berries, citrus peel/rind, peppercorn, pine, wheat, cracker, white bread, and herbal/floral/grassy earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of citrus/fruity/tropical/earthy hops and moderate pale/wheat malt notes; with great strength. Taste of big tangerine, red grapefruit, lemon, peach, pineapple, passion fruit, mango, melon, berries, citrus peel/rind, peppercorn, pine, wheat, cracker, white bread, and herbal/floral/grassy earthiness.  Light-moderate pine, citrus peel/rind, herbal, floral, grassy, peppery bitterness on the finish. Lingering notes of tangerine, red grapefruit, lemon, peach, pineapple, passion fruit, mango, melon, berries, citrus peel/rind, peppercorn, pine, wheat, cracker, white bread, and herbal/floral/grassy earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/fruity/tropical/earthy hops and moderate pale/wheat malt flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance, and no lingering hop astringency after the finish. Moderately crisp/clean finishing. Moderate increasing dryness from bitterness. Medium carbonation and light-medium body; with a very smooth, moderately bready/grainy/sticky, and fairly resinous/rindy balanced mouthfeel that is great. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 4%. Overall this is an awesome session IPA. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/fruity/tropical/earthy hops and moderate pale/wheat malt flavors; very smooth, crisp, clean, and refreshing to drink with the moderately bitter/resinous/drying finish, not overly aggressive. Very flavorful and not watery for the ABV. Feels like Simcoe, Galaxy, Amarillo, Columbus, Centennial. Very vibrant, dank, earthy, and fairly juicy hops; with a nice solid wheat/oat/malt backbone for the ABV. No residual sweetness from crisp dryness. A really enjoyably offering, and impressive style example. One of the better ones available, especially considering the lower ABV/calories with the newer batches.

Bottle. Amber with a sinking but lasting white head. Beefy hop nose with strong citrus. On one hand it makes me appreciate maltier bigger iPAs but on the other I like the goal; hops without an ABV that stops the day. Citrus and citra. Light delicate malt  could have called it Quaff.
Slightly hazy straw gold.  Heavy aroma of deep pine with a bit of garlic and onion.  Flavor is more delicate with moderate pine bitterness and citrusy biscuit malt.  Very light and refreshing.

Bottle. Crystal clear bright gold pour with a small white head. Very nice tropical fruit / grapefruit aroma. Light and crisp palate. Nice carbonation and hop zing on the taste. Easy drinking, very solid. Lagunitas gets it done once again.

Bottle. Is this a great beer? No. Is this a pretty damn impressive product at 4.65% ABV? I think so. Pours clear pale golden with a small white head and minimal lacing. Aroma is grapefruit and pine. Flavor is the same with a strong herbal note, lightly sweet and lightly bitter. Body is light and overall a bit watery, but hey, its 4.65%!

Bottle.  Fluffy white head with good lacing, clear light marigold hue. Catty, some tropical fruit, and grapefruit. Flavor is quite catty, nicely dank and grapefruit with drying earthy finish. Lighter body and a touch cottony. Solid

Pint  at Tylers,  good aroma, sweet. Citrusy. Grapefruit, orange. Clean yellow gold color, minor head, no lace. Bitter sweet flavor. Light body, thin watery mouthfeel, bitter finish. Nice. Easy drinking , aroma was best part, flavor not.as appealing.aroma had nice Citrusy notes, flavor more steely bitterness.

Bottle.  A solid golden color with a diminished white head.  A relatively strong hop aroma with grapefruit, lemon, and dry grass.  It has a nice little bitter bite and goes down smoothly.  The body is relatively light, which was expected.  I like it.  This beer fills a great niche.

12 ounce bottle from Whole Foods Market Charlottesville. Pours a clear pale amber color with a medium sized frothy white head. Decent head retention. Aroma of fruity, floral, tropical, citrus and resin hops. The taste is toasted malts with citrus, tropical and herbal notes. Medium bodied, lingering bitterness, prickly feel. Nice.

Bottle from drabmuh. Thanks Matt!

The beer is absolutely crystal clear and pale yellow hued with a small white head. The aroma is fabulous. Hops galore with notes of tropical fruit. Malt? What malt? The flavor is quit nice. Hop forward, extremely light in body. A quaffable summer brew. I definitely recommend this beer.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a clear light amber with a pillowy white head that has good retention and leaves a large amount of lacing on the glass.  The aroma is mango, watermelon, a bit of pine, and some grapefruit.  A hint of pineapple as well.  Taste is dry with mango, watermelon, and a bit of pine.  There is just a bit of caramel malt.  The finish is dry with a light bitterness.  Light bodied.  Medium carbonation.  Pretty tasty for a low alcohol beer, although I’m not sure why it’s priced higher than most of their regular lineup.
Bottle - average size foamy head, bright yellow color, fair pine hop aroma and flavor, mild sweet malt balance

12oz brown bottle. Yellow pour, big frothy white head. Lots of lacing. Huge hoppy nose, mix of pine and grapefruit, sharp orange and a hint of dank. Taste is highly hoppy with grapefruity notes, some tropical fruitiness and a mild soapiness, bit of orange, light malt. Finishes dryly, medium amount of bitterness carries through, grapefruity hops linger. Light body, medium carbonation. Overall, a nice brew, great aroma, high drinkability, even though the soapiness detracts from it just a tiny bit and the body seems a little thin. Worth trying.

Boldly hopped, especially for such a low-alcohol beer. But that’s a good thing if you like hoppy/bitter beers and want something sessionable and/or low alcohol. Light golden with a thin, quickly fading head. Refreshing and effervescent, and it isn’t thin and watery like many ~4% beers out there. Malts are light, crackery and hay-like. Hop bitterness is high -- grassy and somewhat stark. Hop flavors and aromas are very floral. It’s a good "easy drinker" for hopheads.

Sampled at the Artisans Craft Beer Festival 2012.  It poured a clear golden color with a thick white head. The aroma was of pine and resin hops. The taste was of pine, resin, and light floral hops with a touch of malt sweetness.  Very good APA.

12 oz bottle into a pint glass.

A - Pours a very light golden body. Small one finger head settles down to thin edging. Light lacing and retention.

S - Fantastic aroma that certainly emanates a larger beer profile. Papaya and mango, bitter grapefruit, and some light caramel malts. Very strong hop aroma.

T - Falls a bit flat against the aroma. Traces of tropical fruit over a large crackery malt base. Not particularly bitter. Has a light almost watery finish. Mouth feel is well carbonated but quite light.

O - I’m not sure whether I want to hate or love this beer. It certainly succeeds in its goal of a tasty and hoppy session IPA. That seems to be its downfall though. For me a $12 sixer of an IPA should just pack more flavor than this. I could easily down an entire six pack, but I think a beer like SNPA is just more practical cost wise.

Pale gold pour with thick frothy head. Nose is huge citrus hops. Hops ate fainter on taste and fade back nicely. Faint maltiness and pine. Nice easy drinker

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The beer has a medium yellow color with a nice head. The aroma is like an IPA with pine and flowers. The taste is a little tart and light. I was expecting a little more but it seemed to be missing something to give it a full flavor. There was some apples and herbs but fell off quick. Medium finish.

A - Pours a clear golden-orange with a finger of frothy white head. The head fades down at a normal pace leaving behind some nice lacing.
