S - Aroma is a mix of grapefruit and pine hops with some sweet caramel and biscuit malts.

T - Starts off with a mix of grapefruit and citrus hops with some bitterness and some sweet caramel malts. Through the middle, some pine and grassy hops come through with some more bitterness and some biscuit malts. The finish is a mix of sweet biscuit and caramel malts with grapefruit and pine hops and some bitterness.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a dry and bitter finish.

D - Very drinkable. Nice sessionable IPA with a good hop profile and hop and malt balance.

The aroma on this is very hoppy with plenty of floral character.  Also has some lemon character, too.  Not much in the way of malt aroma.  Transparent golden body with a rocky, white head that is pretty strong.  Starts with a bit of an astringent hop bitterness.  Some lemon character.  Light toasty cereal malt flavors come through in the middle, before this finishes mildly bitter with floral and lemon flavors.  A nice beer.
Nice, crisp, pine and citrus aroma with light doughy malts. The flavor is fairly dry and lightly bitter. The hopping is nice, with plenty of citrus. Malts are a bit dull. Very enjoyable beer overall.
Bottle courtesy of Ben and Stephanie, thanks!  Pale yellow, small white head, solid lacing. Aroma is really nice fresh grass, weeds, scallions. Taste is bitter, fruity, grassy. Very nice.

Bottle-purchased at Davidson liquors in Littleton, CO SEP 2012-pours bright clear lite orange with a small soapy white head.  Doesnt look like anything special yet is clear and clean.  nose is bigtime hops-lots of green onion, spice, citrus (grapefruit), tangerine, and some medicinal notes and a hint of cheese.  smells like a big beer, for such a small beer.  flavors exhibit all the above characteristics but delivered in a beer that i can slam at anytime!  If there were a Light IPA, this would be it.  One of the best session beers i have ever had!  I wish i had more of this stuff!  A bit pricey ($10 or so for a 6pk), but definately solid beer!  Reminds me somewhat of the summer love from Victory.  hard to beat a low abv ipa like this!

Bought a sixer after a small sample at the bottle shop.  Very similar to the similarly themed Founders All Day IPA.  Nose is nice, lots of citrus, tropical fruits, light resins and light caramel.  Flavor is okay at first, but the hops get more and more resinous as you drink it, onion/garlic notes creep in, lots of herbal bitterness bodering on astringent.   Shows promise, but falls a little short.  Still, i like the trend.

A golden body with a thin white coating for a head which did not last long.  A slight presence of carbonation.  Aroma had a nice toasted malt note to it hops were slightly bitter and slightly grassy.  Flavor had a nice mild malt base, mostly cereal grains hops were bitter which at times seemed astringent.  Mostly soft flavors  Carbonation was slightly elevated.  Decent beer

Bottle from BevMo: Poured a crystal clear golden liquid with a frothy topping of head. Nose is decked with oily green hops and smells as if this was meant to be a wet hop IPA. The same can’t be said about the flavor though since it is less tame than the aroma lead me to believe with only a pinch of hops. The malts and the hops do balance each other making this somewhat tasty session ale.

Clean sharp yellow pour with one finger of wispy white head.  Nose is very nice,  pungent and hoppy with notes of garlic and onion followed up by fresh hop cones and ’dankness’.  Some resin comes through,  lightly peppery too. Grassy flavor with a lightly peppery quality, not as much of the fine/delicate hop character here.  Light body,  not too dry or astringent.  Cool

12 oz. bottle. Pours a slightly cloudy golden yellow with a small, frothy white head. Nose and flavor are marked by slight sauvin-style cat piss, hints of apricot and orange, candied sugars, and lovely lemongrass. Really nice complex hop profile for such a low alcohol brew. I’m definitely a fan.

Bottle from Rick’s in Alexandria.  Served in a Lagunitas shaker pint glass.  Pours a clear straw color with a good head and plenty of lacing.  Nose has a nice backing citrus and tropical aroma. Very light grain. Flavor is quite nice with light tropical notes. Moderately bitter.  Light body and extremely drinkable.

Bottle poured a clear gold with a lasting white head. Aromas of  earthiness, , lemons and light grapefruit. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of,earthiness, lemon and light grapefruit with a crisp dry lingering bitter finish.

Bottle. Moderate grain and roasted for the malt, heavy pine for the hops, moderate soap for the yeast, with hints of pineapple, ginger and pepper. Head is average sized, frothy white with excellent thick lacing and is fully lasting. Color is sparkling clear light yellow. Flavor is faintly sweet and moderately acidic to start, then finishes lightly acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is on the fuller side of medium, watery with a lively to fizzy carbonation. Looks like a pilsener, but the aroma of this American Pale Ale is very IPA-ish. Great beer.

Bottle.  Really good beer.  I wish it was a little less alchol but it has awesome aroma and taste.  the lacing is great.  Orange color with white fluffy head.  If this was about 3% I could drink this all day but its still a bit high to drink tons of it.  Very nice Job.

Small white head thats short lived with very little lace to speak of.Slight chill haze to this urine,straw colored brew. Nose is nicely piney and floral, quaint fruitiness. Body is light, almost watery, under carbonated and a bit juicy. Tame hop flavors of pine, citrus, lil pissy with a hint of grainy malts lazin about. Dry finish with a crisp bite. Glad to see it got re-catagorized to an APA because thats what it is and not one of the better ones i,ve had.  Still a quaffable brew at a fair price. 6er from statelineliquors.

Whoa.  Where has this beer been all my life?  A sub-5%, dry, well-attenuated, sessionable IPA that is widely distributed and under $10 for a 6-pack?  Home run Lagunitas.  Home-freaking-run.  The pour yields a crystal clear, deep golden body with a taught, dense head of barely off-white froth.  Skinny streaks of lace mark the glass.  The nose explodes with juicy hops, showing notes of pineapple and clementine, with secondary waves of pine and a bit of dank grass.  Underlying malts are softly toasted, kind of white-bready really, and they mostly stay out of the way.  Flavors are perfectly balanced.  Quite hoppy at nearly 60 IBU, the citrus and pine show plenty of crisp bite, but the deliciously toasted, clean malt base adds just enough roundness.  The palate begs for gulp after gulp, plenty light but still hearty enough to satisfy.  Carbonation is spot on and crisp.  Excellent beer.  Get it fresh and drink it by the gallon – or just leave it all for me.  That’d be cool too.   I’m sure it wasn’t easy to execute in such volume, but they really nailed it on this one.

Pour out of 12 oz bottle, clear orange, mainly yellow with nice fluffy lasting white head.  Aroma brought notes of big dank pine, sweet orange, grapefruit, some slight garlic notes but not much, hints of simcoe cat pee as well, touch of biscuit and bready notes.  Taste is a mix of orange peel, grapefruit, pine, touch of biscuit, some slight cat pee, hints of vanilla, grass and pine, finishing very bitter, almost too much.  Very refreshing, and nice to drink at only around 4.5%
Pours clear and golden.  Has that great, distinct Lagunitas aroma that I enjoy.  Lacks the punch of Lagunitas IPA... which is pretty much the idea of this beer.  It’s good.

On tap at Lagunitas. Clear gold hued pour with a white head. Aromas are fruity, hoppy, and grainy. Nice citrus hop character, low ester. Flavors are grainy, toasty and dry. Good fruity hop character, light esters, medium bitterness. Lively bubbles, dry and a bit thin. 

Bottle rerate: crystal clear yellow pour with a fully retentive large white head. All hops on the aroma: mango, grassy, tangerine, tropical fruit, pine. All hops. Flavors are great. Bready to crackery malt, light ester, medium bitterness. Grassy, tangerine and mango like hop flavors. Excellent. Light dry and crisp, lower carbonation than I would like.
yellow straw color, aroma of grain, bread, grass, pine, flavors are the same, very light and easy to drink, lots of flavors for such a small beer
Floral aroma.  Sweet taste with a little pine.  A little too floral for me.  This one isn’t overly interesting, but could be an all day drinker for sure.
Light orange in color... Aroma of floral and piney hops... Flavor is light caramel malt body with nice piney and citrus hop finish... Solid but not memorable
Not too malty, slightly sugar cookie in the malt delivery. Hops aren’t over the top but enough to enjoy this lighter IPA.

WAY too pine-forward for me.  I like much of Lagunitas’ stuff, but this was very imbalanced - basically piney hops and little else.  Not much of a malt backbone or anything else to keep it interesting.  Disappointed.

Clear and bubbly light yellow pour with a thick fluffy white head.  Hops dominate the nose and tongue.  Very funky, sticky, weedy, and resinous.  At first seemed a bit watery, unbalanced, and overly bitter.  The malt came through with a light sweetness as it warmed up.  Overall, an enjoyable beer.

Tallahassee, Fl - Market Square Liquors - 12 oz bottle. Dark golden, sparkling, with a light white head. Fragrant aroma with a mixture of spearmint and cat urine....in a good way.  Flavor has a unique spiciness to it with some sour lemony accents, a touch of spearmint, some grainy spiciness - grains of paradise perhaps, a touch of apricot fruitness. Mouthfeel has a nice spritz to it. Nice, pleasant mouthfeel. Keep making ’em Lagunitas, I will keep buying and rating them!

On tap at brewery. Clear dark yellow with a fizzy white head. Grassy citrus and pine hops. Lively medium bodied palate. Earthy bitter pine and light resin taste with a musty citrus finish and light bitterness.
From the 12oz bottle. Big piney aromatic citrus hop aroma just huge. Light crisp malt with a really well halved citrus hop bite. Awesome brew.

Keep it in the bottle: It’s not pretty. Keep it in the bottle: It tastes better this way. It’s thin, but drinkable. It’s the opposite of a sipper, but I’ll stick to their normal IPAs. They’re better off making a beer that’s half IPA, half juice -- hm, ... Inspirational. In other words, there’s not enough body for this to work so I’d rather "low alcohol" beers be made like a pilsner, etc.

Interesting little beer. Bland pour with a clear straw color and a light white head. The nose has a fantastic hop forward, citrus based aroma with not much else. EEasy to drink with a light malt and light citrus hops and mild bitterness. Overall very subtle but still tasty.
Smells amazing, looks amazing, but very light IPA, still sometime you will enjoy

Big hops on the aroma. Appears a pale golden color with a decent foam. Standard hops upfront with a small bitterness in the back. Subtle caramel malts floating about. Overall, it’s good but it’s nothing special. A very basic yet, well done IPA. B rating.

Clear golden pour with a foamy white head. Aroma is strongly dominated by floral and citrus hops with grapefruit, oranges and peach. Lots of piney and citrus with hints of pils malt in the flavor that ends clean and crisp. Pretty tasty and great session beer.

Pours clear pale golden color with white head. Simcoe hop aroma with some lightly toasted malts. Bitter hop flavor with some grass and pine. Very little malt flavor. Light to medium body with average carbonation.  Most lagunitas beers are overly malty; this one could use a little more malt flavor.

Pours a carbonated golden with a nice white head.  Lots of grapefruit in the aroma, along with melon, hops, and mango.  Taste contains plenty of pine to go along with a hoppy flavor.  Grapefruit impressions remain and there is a noticeable lemon zest.  Dry throughout, with piney lemony aftertaste.  Medium bodied with a good amount of lively carbonation.  This really plays like a big boy beer without the strong alcohol content.  As advertised, this one is perfect for consuming throughout the day.

Bottle. Pours a very light and clear golden color with a big white head. Aroma is big hops with a big of onion/garlic and dankness. Reminiscent of Lagunitas Sucks. Not sure what that hop profile is but it is distinctive. Taste is somewhat watery at the front but then there is a nice hop balance. Strong peach in the middle as the beer warms. This is a rad low alcohol IPA. Kinda like Founders All Day IPA but available to me and not insanely over priced.

Bottle. Pours clear gold color with a big sudsy white head that slowly settles to a film and plenty of lacing. Aroma has noticeable floral earthy hops and there some what pungent. Taste is nice and bitter with earthy floral hops with spruce as well and a malty finish. Palate is clean and a little sticky with a drying finish. Really tasty, and a few will go done easy!
12oz bottle. Pours a light golden with a medium white head. Huge hop aroma and taste. The malt flavors are a bit overwhelmed by the hops but it works. Pretty good IPA considering the low ABV.
Bottle.  Cloudy yellow with thin white head.  Full tangerine hop aroma, very nice.  Medium bodied, more hop with a bit of malt.  Light finish, hop tang on the roof of the mouth

Bottle, courtesy GT2, thanks! Bright gold pour, big white head, some retention/good lace. Aroma of kumquat, melon, citrus hops, very light toast. Taste is somewhat bitter, melon/kumquat hops. Palate is dry, soft, slick, bitter finish. One of the better’session IPAs.

Simcoe/Citra hop aromas with a clear, straw colored pour. Lacy white head lingers for quite a while. A very crisp, hoppy, and lightly malted. This is definitely one of my favorite sessionable IPAs of this year, and ever (Brau Brothers Hopsession is the other).

I had trouble with this beer - do I rate it based on its goals? a 4/12%ABV IPA/PA?  Because if so, I this ranks right up there with one of the best 4.5% beers I have had.  Hell, it has an incredible hop aroma when I popped the top, and 10x more flavor that any 5% corn-based slop produced by the majors.  Just as I expected, very crisp, clean, dry as they come - and I agree with other reviewers - this could easily be a nice hoppy pale ale. The appearance was pretty boring with a clear yellow pour, but I quibble.  a very nice lower alcohol product, and I am glad I bought 2 sixers of this limited release.  Please make this a full-timer, guys!
Clear Straw Pour with small white head. Big resiny hop nose. Light body body. Slightly sweeter finish. Good Session obviously but would rather be drinking their IPA or the WTF or Sumthin Wild.

Appearance:  Pours a straw gold with a modest soapy cap of white foam. Holding it up to the light, you will notice some very active rising bubbles in the clear body.



Aroma: Beautiful big citrusy danky nose, fresh grass. Pretty close to opening a pack of hop pellets. Some candied orange too as it warms.



Taste: A punch of citrusy hops, very dry pale malt, a little earthy hop bitterness that finishes very clean. Medium duration for the lingering hop bitterness.



Mouthfeel: Thin and on the high side in terms of carbonation.



Overall: Amazingly tasty and drinkable. A beer this small can show some flaws, and I’m glad to report there are none.

perfect balance of bitter and aromatic hop expresssion. lean dry body with minimal malt contribution clean and non estery with light cereals and biscuit. dank, cannabis aromas, some tropical fruit. A ballsy beer that hits the target square. Still lots of texture and without sweetness or flabby body. KUDOS!

Bottle poured a clear gold with a lasting whiote head. Aromas of crackers, earthiness, cat piss, lemon zest and light grapefruit. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of crackers,earthiness, lemon zest and light grapefruit with a crisp dry lingering bitter finish.
12 oz bottle from Safeway Salinas. Nose is pine, grapefruit, and a hint of mango. Slightly hazed yellow with a big white head. Flavor is bitter (what else) with a smattering of piney resin.

Pour is clear medium gold with a medium foamy white head.
aroma is pungent resiny, pine, pineapple/citrus fruit hop. 
Flavour is fruit and pine light biscuity malt. Somewhat muted but still enjoyable.

Bottle shared at the September 2012 Santa Cruz tasting. Pours clear gold with a small white head. Great minimal malt character, but the hoppiness is way too subdued. If they packed a ton of hops on top of the crisp pils malty base, this would be really good. But they didn’t.

12 oz. bottle - Pours a crystal clear golden color with a one finger thick white head.  Very light lacing.  Aroma is big pine and resin hops.  Flavor is pine, resin, and light floral hops with a touch of malt sweetness trying to break through.  Finish is crisp and hoppy.  Medium body.  A good beer.  I love these Lagunitas IPA’s.
Out of the bottle from Uptown. Pours clear golden with not much of a head. Smell is hoppy, but the taste is sour instead. Not my favorite beer from Lagunitas.

9/8/12. 12oz bottle from Grassroots. Clear golden pour with a surprisingly almost bright white head that sticks around and laces plenty. Really nice hop aroma with citrus, pine, dank hops, a touch of cat pee, and a bit of creamy, caramelly malt. Similarly bold, dank hop flavor with a bit of sour citrus in there as well and more of that creamy malt. A bit light on the body, but that is to be expected. Not bad!

Bottle.  Pours light gold with a small head.  Great hop aroma.  Initial taste had some hops up front and a brief flash of malt, but then the bitterness took over and covered up the malt for the rest of the bottle which was a shame.  A good idea for a beer, but a little too bitter for my tastes

This smells like a red ale.  Squat, west coast potato masher bottle.  Clear gold.  Smells like cat whiz -- piney, urea. Sweet, fruity notes at times.  Brothy, dry, herbal. Medium body.  Flabby and not crisp. Vegetable, light diacetyl finish. Market Square Liquors.

Bottle from ck1 - thanks bro! Pours a very clear pale golden yellow with a white head. Nice lacing. Aroma has pine needles, resin, some citrus and a vegetalness. Taste is very light and crisp; sweet fruit, resin, lemon peels and a bit of a quirky off-taste (a strange herb?). Finishes very lightly, with more bitterness than sweetness. The idea of this style is very good, and have seen multiple versions lately (Founders, O’so) that probably were started with that terrific San Diego session ale of Stone’s. Easy drinker. Mostly good tasting.

355mL. Low haze starfruit pour. Medium soapy white head. Leaving complete soapy lace. Nose is heavier kumquat pulp, fresh flowers. Taste is meaty kumquat, very clean with some soapiness. Palate is very thin and refreshing. Like IPA-lite or APA. Not bad. Good session stuff. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle...  Poured mildly hazy, mostly filtered (fractionally?) pale golden/yellow with a white head that faded quickly to a thin lace on the surface of the beer. Grassy, earthy, pine-like, resinous hops on the nose. Flavor wise the hops played the same role as the aroma. Not much body or malt. A nice session beer with a distinguished hop character. Is this their answer to Pale 31?

Bottle from hophead father Conor. Clear straw pour with big white head. Aroma is tons of hops with a hint of onion. I think they used some simcoe hops. Very crisp and refreshing yet hoppy. Can you say beer pong!

Poured from the bottle, I think they hit the nail on the head of what they tried to brew, I’ve looked for this all summer, a light ipa!  Love it! Aroma indicates citrusy hops. Flavour as well. Palate its thinner than a pale ale. Its not to style, but it’s what they tried to brew and it’s great! Looking forward to trying ’Night Time.’

Clear straw color with very little head. Aroma is lightly floral. Flavor is mildly bitter. Very crisp and refreshing palate. A good beer all around. It’s a bit weaker than what I expect from Lagunitas, but on the other hand, it is very clean, crisp, and refreshing.
